content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												Quake is a single-player and multiplayer FPS developed by id software and released 1996. It got quite infamous and is recognised today as classic. It was one of the first FPS to fully use polygons to create game enviroment and established multiplayer over Internet on PC.So, how Steam was handled? It's pretty straight copy-paste. Copy-paste of game folder. Not of game's CD. And that means that music is not just not working, but it's not even included to begin with! You will have to find somewhere soundtrack or music files or CD to get it back. And if mounting CD will not work for you, then I would recommend getting music files and _inmm software to fix it. And even then it looped too early. Soundtrack is quite important in this game, even though I have a bad feeling that most remember this Quake without it.Now, when you launch the game you will be given the choice between running Quake or Quakeworld. You also will have to choose between Software and OpenGL versions of each.Quake, also known as WinQuake, is actually a Windows-compilated version of Quake. There wasn't much difference. It's for both Single-player and multiplayer.QuakeWorld is stricly competive multiplayer. This client was released some time after Quake and was intented to make it more playable on low-speed Internet modems back then. Different way of handling server-client relations.Software is original Quake rendering. Pixelated, gritty and dark. Lo-fi. I recommend playing game in this mode on low resolution, like in DOS release, it captures Quake feel better than most other fans Source Port. Or OpenGl.OpenGL mode was added some time after game's release and made use of new-by-then hardware 3D accelration. And well, it's not pretty. First, it lacks some features when it comes to lighting. There is no such thing is "brighter than grey" and there are no special textures that are always full-bright. And then the main point of this mode if to make game look more high-resolution. By making every texture look muddy and uglier, actually. I mean, you can like such thing only if you really hate pixels.And last thing, once you start playing, write "+mlook" command in console, that you can open with "`" keyboard key. This will enable mouselook. Why it's not part of game's options I don't know, especially seeing how demos make use of mouse in such way.Plot of single-player is once again simple: There is unknown enemy that was given codename "Quake", who teleports it's army through slipgate. And now that your base was overrun, you have to make use of slipgate to travel to other otherwordly dimension, find out who "Quake" actually is through intermission text and then kick it's butt in most gimmicky way. And then watch the oh so epic bright ending in form text where you are told "id software salutes you".That pretty much means that you got 4 episodes to choose from beggining, you lose equpment in beggining of each one, the first level of each episode is base themed and actually has unique enemies and then you are off to medieval-like setting.And yes, when it comes to single-player, one of the best things Quake got to offer was atmosphere. Gritty. Dark. Well, ugly brown at times. you fight some kind of monsters in their low polygonal details. You get weapons like nailgun. It just has a bit of lovecraftian inspiration to it. There are even traps placed here and there. Bloody bloody traps. Soundtrack, while small, contributes a lot to it. And then there are some maps in Episode 4 which play strong on lights blinking or shadows being pitch dark, all in small rooms. Quake is at it's best in such levels. I am pretty sure that people who thought that Doom was scary back then were blown by Quake.And when you look at more gameplay side of it, well, on theory it should be like Doom but worse. It's slower. Physics are slightly worse, you stop completely upon encountering walls. There is less variety in weapons, even though they introduces grenade launcher, yet some weapons are just direct upgrades to others. Like, Super Shotgun isn't even good at close range, not as much as Super Nailgun. Just something when you run out of ammo on other weapons. There aren't as many enemies, nor as much of variety. You can say that half of Quake gameplay is shooting two rockets at the Ogre, who has grenade launcher and chainsaw. Or shooting 4 times with Super Shotgun at them. And it's too grey at times.But somehow game pulls through and becomes quite fun. Even if there are less enemies on the levels, it got quite a nice combat to it. And for a game that is supposed to be rushed, level design is great. It got verticality, it is mazey but not too complex, it just has floors on top of each other, fully embracing the fact that game is fully 3D now.You would think that first introduction to fully polygonal world would be quite underwhelming. That it will underuse it and later games will make it better. But no, Quake still has some good layouts, better than many later games. Should thank that talents at id software were still thinking in abstarct ways, didn't try to be as realistical as Build engine games like Duke Nukem 3D.It still got some weak points though. Like, Vores, spiders-like demons who shoot homing missiles. Actually, their missiles track players so good, that one corner is not enough to stop them and you can't circlestrafe around them. I don't understand what is the point, what kind of tactic developers wanted to use there. That, and game underdelivers on boss departament. There are only two "proper" bosses in the whole game. And when I say "proper", I actually just mean gimmicky ones.As for Deathmatch and duel parts, the multiplayer side, well, it's not so good. It made multiplayer over Internet more mainstream and common, yes. But the game balance, it doesn't age too well. It's only good on high-level of play, but same can be said about many games. Yes, it's not Quake-exclusive quality, don't tell me.You mostly have to dominate arena by grabbing most powerful weapons and powerups. Red Armor is better than any other armor, as it not only gives more armor points, but actually is more effective too. Rocket Launcher shoot quite fast missiles which are too quick to avoid properly. It's also most powerful weapon and most used one. Aside from lighting gun, which is good alternative too. Things die fast there.So, you just have to grab superior weapons and powerups and then go roflstomp everything else, including those who just spawned in.It gets even better once you realize that players are actively exploiting glitches in physic engine, like bunnyhopping and voodoo-like strafejumping, thigns that don't make a single sense. It become a standard nowadays, thus creating an artificial barrier between high-level and low-level players, where you have to practice much more than you should have to be as good and have some fighting chances.So yea, casuals should avoid. Normal players should avoid.You will have ot use server finders on Internet. And then chances are, there will be barely anybody playing. But then, most still play Quake for duels, so it must not be big issue.Still better than Valve's Deathmatch Classic.So yea, game's quality itself is good, but not groundbreaking. Just good game. But what made Quake so overpraised is technical side. The engine. First, it introduced console. Then it allows you to record demos, thus creating competiveness where players try their best and creating some kind of "public". Then when you combine it with glitchy physics, you will see how Speedrunning was created. And then multiplayer was more focused on Internet public. And even better, game allowed more modding abilities, much more than in original Doom. And then it allowed modding in multiplayer. Thus creating Team Fortress mod, for example. And Capture the Flag mode too.So, yes. Technical amazement, good single-player and finey multiplayer. This is the first Quake.

												This is pretty much the 3D version of Doom (Well, before Doom 3 came out) so if you liked that game, you're gonna love this one. Let me tell you why:The Pros:-It has great variety in its weapons, enemies and levels-The graphics (For its time) are great-The sound effects are awesome-The controls are smooth-The game can be REALLY challenging (Especially if you play on the Hard or Nightmare modes)-The enemies are, also, challenging (Again, if you play on the higher difficulties)-There's alot of secrets you can find in the game (Much like Doom 1 & 2 did)The Cons:-There's no music for the Steam version (Thankfully, you can get a source port called Darkplaces which adds the music back in)-The game is really short if you play on the lower difficulties (Easy & Normal)-No proper final boss fight like its successor, Quake 2, didAll in all, this is a game I recommend. content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												Is this the last "classical" FPS?  Or the first "modern" shooter?  After nearly two decades I'm not even sure anymore.  All brown jokes aside, consider the following:* Graphics and lighting that have aged beautifully, unless you're an unrepentant graphics ♥♥♥♥♥.* Incredibly immersive sound design and score by Trent Reznor that beats most games today (playing SP campaign in the dark with headphones can get ridiculously unnerving)* FAST, FLUID, SKILLFUL GAMEPLAY -- YOU CAN AND WILL DIE.  BRUTALLY.And I'm not even going to talk about the mods, or multiplayer, or any of that other stuff we take for granted thanks to the breakthroughs this game made.  We all know.  It's not much more than a slight update of the DOOM formula, without ever really hitting those same heights, but I keep coming back to this game once in a while simply because - well, because they don't make them like this anymore.  There's the most grudging attempt at a story, not nearly as many enemies as you'd like, and a confusing mish-mash of design elements owing to the chaos at iD.  But it's a classic anyway, and IMO the last great iD title, because it just wants to be fun and atmospheric.  And it succeeds.Boot it up.  Blow off some steam.  Gib some grunts.  Axe a dog.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												This is one of the best games ever made, and certainly my favourite despite the huge number of other mind-numbingly awesome games I have played. Whilst the original game might not stand up in some ways to modern FPS games, its focus on simple satisfying carnage, and near total lack of a story or any semblance of realism to get in ther way of said carnage makes it one of the most pure and enjoyable FPS games in existence.The main game is fairly short, but there are so many add-on levels and mods, you could easily be playing this for hundreds of hours without running out of new content. It also supports coop play, so you can blast through the main game and various mods together, and when you get sick of coop, you play one of the first ever deathmatch FPS games. Although Doom had deathmatch, it was Quake that caused an explosion in its popularity, and through mods spawned many new deathmatch modes, such as CTF and even Team Fortress.Although there have been games since that have tried to bring players the classic gameplay focussed carnage of Quake and Doom, few have come anywhere near to the greatness of the originals. You'd be mad not to try this game if you've never played it before.Disclaimer: I played Quake from 1996 when it came out. I still play now from time to time. I don't play the Steam version, hence I don't have much recorded playtime (just played ep1 to get enough to write this review! Still fun as hell).Also, although the Steam version of the game works fine, I recommend getting hold of modern engine, such as Quakespasm to play it with. Check out the website Quaddicted to get new levels, mods and engines.

Quake Engines, Old and New 
A Guide for Quake
By: Johnny Law

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 4, 2013
												Quake is a game that is difficult to describe accurately. It is an experience that takes everything you think you know about first person shooters gets thrown out the window and replaced by a new standard.Quake is the first truly 3D first person game, no longer are the enemies and objects in the world represented by mere 2D sprites but are instead rendered in full glorious 3D letting you view them from every angle. This also opens up the maps and up, down, left and right are now all equal and most all be checked to find that one pesky monster shooting at you.The weapons are plentiful and varied from the grenade launcher which, thanks to the 3D engine, can be used to bounce grenades off walls and ceilings to hit enemies that are hiding to the iconic lightning gun and extremely entertaining nail gun. All the weapons have excellent sound effects and animations and use them efficiently leaves you feeling powerful.Using the weapons efficiently however requires more skill than ever before, aiming in the general direction of your enemies will not suffice and only a steady mouse hand will prevail against the alien hordes.Map design is of an equally high quality with a great emphasis on atmospheric lightning and a decent about of nooks and crannies to find hidden goodies in. The multi-player maps are equally well balanced and will reward only the most skilled among you.Throughout the maps, both single- and multi-player, you will encounter power-ups that grant you various short lived bonuses such as increased damage, more health, invisibility and other good stuff. Knowledge of their locations can quickly turn defeat into victory for the observant player.Graphically there is not much to say. Quake simply sets the bar and it is up to the rest of the world to follow.An excellent soundtrack sets the mood throughout the game and creates a dark and tense atmosphere that only increases as you progress through the levels.All in all Quake is perhaps the greatest first person shooter every released simply because of how many firsts it can boast. Without it nothing would be the same and for that reason alone this is a game that no self respecting gamer can go without.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
Quake is a first person shooter released by id Software in 1996. One of the earliest 3D shooters, Quake became the basis for shooters beyond it for years to come, like Doom before it. Quake was also one of the most popular games to mod. Aforementioned mods also spawned franchises that are still popular today, such as Counter-Strike and Team Fortress.Quake's artstyle is one that immediately stands out, it's very Lovecraftian, with indescribably horrifying monsters and huge creepy castles.The sound design is great too. Trent Reznor of Nine Inch Nails fame was brought in to do the music and sounds, and they're absolutely fantastic. With creepy ambient sound effects, and horrific monster voices, the whole game's atmosphere is practically made by the sound design. The biggest problem with all of this, is that the Steam version doesn't contain the soundtrack, so you need to download a patch to add them back in, or simply put the original cd in if you have it.Back to the aforementioned castles, the levels largely consist of maze-like castles and fortresses filled with secrets and monsters. Powerups, weapons, and shortcuts are all hidden behind secret doors and in the shadows. The level-design overall is par for the course when it comes to old-school id, meaning it kicks major♥♥♥♥♥The weapons are pretty varied, with shotguns, nailguns, rocket and grenade launchers, pretty much all the tropes that these games invented, Quake has. It has a few powerups too, these being the Quad Damage, Pentagram of Protection, and the Ring of Shadows. Enemy variety is also fantastic, with some enemies that are explosive resistant, others that need to be blown to smithereens, otherwise getting back up and continuing the fight. The multiplayer isn't really active, although it's still great for lan parties.ProsSolid, if simple, gameplayGreat map designArtstyle was original for games back then, and is still somewhat original today.Sound design on the level of games like ThiefWeapon and enemy varietyConsSoundtrack is missing in Steam version, requiring a patch to add it back in.Multiplayer isn't very active. Understandable, as the newer games have expanded upon it.Final Thoughts:Quake has a fantastic artstyle and horrifyingly awesome sound design. It's officially 20 years old as of today, and it remains one of the best arena shooters of all time.Rating: 10/10This review was written for and is published on the  Lit Reviews [LR] curator page.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												Brings me back to the good old days of when I had a 100MHz Pentium and 8 megs of RAM...  This game is great for what it does.  It shows where 3 dimensional first person shooters came from.  Yes, one can argue that the genre started with games such as Wolfenstein, Doom, or even Duke 3D...  But fully 3D enemies and environments started here.  Back when video cards were first starting to hit the market and everything was still being done on the CPU.The CPU utilization of the game becomes apparent when you notice just how bad the animations truly are.  You'll first notice it with the dogs and the fact that their legs don't even have a full loop and they simply look silly when they run.  This is a very minor detail when you consider the game's mechanics.The motion of the player is smooth and the guns shoot as you'd expect by today's standards.  This game set a standard that was long followed up until regenerative life was put into games.  I am hoping that the Doom reboot successfully brings the arena shooter genre back.  I appreciate a good story but the action in games of this caliber can make up for all that side♥♥♥♥♥♥  Let's face it, running around with a rocket launcher as your main weapon and blowing everything up is good for your stress and all kinds of fun at the same time.

												So even to this day, there hasn't been a Quake more visually disgusting, and truly macabre. The weird psuedo-gothic horror of character themes and world designs haven't been visited since its debut, (except for Painkiller?)  really, and overall it is a must play. It was the first fully 3d fps on pc and layed the groundwork for what we have today. I will say honestly, it is still enjoyable to this date, after slight tinkering for modern desktop resolutions, is completely enjoyable. Do you even quake? If you haven't been quaking over the porcelain throne that most of all of us use, daily. this game will surely help that next bowel movement pass with ease. I first played this game when I was 6 years old, and it's just as scary as a 25 year old manchild (age of writing this review) Dat grenade launcher sound is awful, the idle npc groans and moans are truly gutteral, flatulent, and thick, like beyonce, you gotta hear it! -Donz

												Rocket Launcher + Quad Damage in multiplayer will let you experience what it's like to have the power of a God at your finger tips... until you're swarmed by enemy boomstickers into a crowded corner and blow everything within the blast radius of a nuclear strike - including yourself - to smithereens. Thus creating a downpour of fleshy limbs, decapitated heads and torsos amidst the mile high blood cascades, painting the entire vicinity into a hellishly beautiful scenery. In short: The most satisfying gib fest-simulator ever made.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												Brings me back to the good old days of when I had a 100MHz Pentium and 8 megs of RAM...  This game is great for what it does.  It shows where 3 dimensional first person shooters came from.  Yes, one can argue that the genre started with games such as Wolfenstein, Doom, or even Duke 3D...  But fully 3D enemies and environments started here.  Back when video cards were first starting to hit the market and everything was still being done on the CPU.The CPU utilization of the game becomes apparent when you notice just how bad the animations truly are.  You'll first notice it with the dogs and the fact that their legs don't even have a full loop and they simply look silly when they run.  This is a very minor detail when you consider the game's mechanics.The motion of the player is smooth and the guns shoot as you'd expect by today's standards.  This game set a standard that was long followed up until regenerative life was put into games.  I am hoping that the Doom reboot successfully brings the arena shooter genre back.  I appreciate a good story but the action in games of this caliber can make up for all that side♥♥♥♥♥♥  Let's face it, running around with a rocket launcher as your main weapon and blowing everything up is good for your stress and all kinds of fun at the same time.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												Quake is a first person shooter that has you traveling through four different dimensions in search of runes that will allow you to fight the main villain. That is pretty much all the story you get and it is up to you to reach the end of each level until you retrieve a ruin and must go to the next dimension. You are free to choose whichever dimension to go to first but I suggest starting from left to right since that introduces all the weapons and enemies much more smoothly. Starting off you must walk into a portal to choose which difficulty you want and to select hard you have to jump over lava which was a nice touch. Your starting weapon is a shotgun, which sounds a lot more awesome than you may think since it is pretty much as useless as the pistol from Doom, disappointingly enough. This is a very fast paced shooter where your moving speed is swifter than that of most games sprinting speed these days, which really comes in handy when there is an enemy pouncing toward you and another is shooting grenades at you. Learning an enemy and it's weaknesses is vital to surviving as you will be under attack by several different types of enemies at once and must learn to choose which one poses the biggest threat or simply how to spot an opening. Like in Doom they will also attack each other if they accidentally hit one another, and that can be very advantageous if you have enough skill to cause the enemies to fight each other to the death, as it saves you both ammo and the risk of taking them on yourself.  It is still exhilarating gameplay after all this time and is just as fun today as it was back then.Environments are still rather acceptable and the atmosphere retains a strong horror vibe to it. Character models have not aged well at all and are rather laughable unfortunately. You will not have time to gawk at them though unless you want a chainsaw to the face. Enemies are pretty versatile since most have both a ranged and close quarters attack. An example is an enemy with a chainsaw attacked to it's arm that will use it when you get too close and a grenade launcher when you are at a distance. That is just one enemy, they usually through multiple types of monsters at you and adapting on the fly is the biggest part of winning a battle. All the enemies are instantly vastly different from one another and instantly recognizable which is a important thing in these type of games. Even a slime is more than capable of killing you if you are not careful.That same level of awareness is necessary when traversing the levels. You are in their world and if something looks to good to be true it most likely is. One thing that I found strange at first is that there is no activate button and you most shoot or simply walk into to switches to activate them. I was unsure how to feel about this at first, but risking a bit of ammo to shoot something that looks out of place and suspicious to find hidden secrets did end up being much better than pressing your face against walls and mashing the activate key like in Doom. Level design is amazing in Quake and each level somehow manages to feel different than the last. The four dimensions do end up blending together in my mind though since they don't really have any real noticeable gimmicks to differentiate them from one another. There is an extra dimension to fight the bad guy but it is a tiny level and ended up being a very disappointing fight.As mentioned before your basic weapon to fend off monsters is a underwhelming shotgun and a fire axe in case you are desperate. There is also a double barreled shotgun you come across later on but it is probably one of the most disappointing shotguns I have used in recent memory. It takes about 5-6 point blank shots to take out some of the most common enemies which makes the game feel bullet spongy  but worse still it burns through ammo which you can only carry 100 of that type. A huge disappointment after the legendary double barreled shotgun from Doom 2. Other weapons fair much better and are a lot more useful. There are two versions of guns that shoot nails and are very useful against enemies though ammo does go by quickly. Your most useful weapon will be a grenade launcher which outputs a huge amount of damage and ammo is plentiful though you will obviously not want to use it when enemies are close by.As is typical from games of this era, there are health kits to replenish your health and armor pickups that will allow you to take more damage. There are other pickups like a hazmat suit that lets you walk on hazards, a quad damage pickup that allows you to completely dominate your foes , a protection pick up that makes you invulnerable for awhile and a golden ring that turns you invisible. Turning invisible sounds cool in theory but once you fire at an enemy they can see you perfectly and avoiding them may not be the wisest choice as you may be attacked by those same enemies if they hear a battle nearby. On the topic of sound one thing that must be mentioned is that the Steam version had all the music removed. I don't know why but if you do not want to mod it back in I wouldn't even bother playing this game.Quake is still a very playable game if you can get past the dated graphics. It is unlike any other shooter released today and is an extinct brand of FPS which is a real shame. If you are buying it expecting multiplayer do know the community is dead and there are no bots so it all falls to the single player. One heck of a campaign though and it should last you about 6 hours. There is no real reason to play it again other than for fun or wanting to try the hidden difficulty mode. It is a perfect game to pick up and play when you are bored since most levels are only 10 to 15 minutes long. If you are on the look out for some fast paced FPS action or simply want to see why the Quake series is held in such high regards by most, Quake 1 is highly recommended.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
												If you're wondering if you should buy Quake, I pity you. You don't know what 'frag' means. You've only played multiplayer online, alone in front of your desk. You think rocket-jumping is a stupid idea.And you, hypothetical person, need to buy Quake. It has fragging. It has a deathmatch multiplayer mode that is fast, frantic and acrobatic. And the rocket jumping? Totally practical, along with strafe-jumping, bunny-hopping, grenade jumping, and the more technical wall-rocket-jumping. Of course you should get Quake. Get four and give Quake to your friends.The world needs more fragging, and the world includes you.It's your duty as a PC gamer to at least play a game that is only slightly less important a shooter than Doom.

content:
Posted: June 1, 2016
												This game has a few issues on steam, luckily they can all be fixed if you just take a very quick look at the forum.Everything still holds up, although there are a couple levels that are a tad dull, perhaps maybe it\'s just my personal taste, but overall the atmosphere, enemies, and levels are all very interestingly designed and you can just tell that the original development team was very excited to do all kinds of weird things with the new engine they were working with.  The levels have tons of different elements to them, constantly mixing jumping, with swimming, with playforming in some area\'s.  They really took advantage of how versatile and free your character was and makes the gameplay feel very dynamic and energetic.Great experience through and through, with 2 expansions in case you want more.  There\'s also a semi-active modding community still around, not sure if it\'s still as active as Doom\'s, but they\'ve produced some great content.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												Quake: The great-grandaddy of 3D/FPS, son of Doom and Heretic, son of Wolfenstein-3D (1992) and Stellar 7 -- The beauty of Quake is that is was the first bona-fide 3D 'engine' in commercial PC games. Releasing the original Quake engine to the dev community was the move that later inspired Valve Software's Gabe Newell to release their own engine-dev environment, "Source", owing to the first Half-Life game being built upon a modified Quake 3D engine. (dubbed "GoldSrc")Quake is easily one of the most significant, if not enjoyable, shooters of all time, with hundreds of different mods (including the original Team Fortress) and is still supported by a rabid fan base. Without Quake, PC gaming would not be what it is today.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
												Quake came out in 1996 and is still one of the best FPS games ever made despite having virtually no plot.  It is all about the gunplay, the level design, and the encounters. And it has all of that in spades.  The actual visuals are dated, but I wouldnt want them changed. They hold up their charm well even after nearly 20 years. On top of all that, the game is moddable to your heart's desire. If you like shooters and want a well dsigned one that is just plain fun to play, then - even by today's standards - look no further.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2015
												Not much is there to be said about Quake. I wouldn't say it's ID's magnum opus, Doom has that title. Quake is still an amazing game. It's lovecraftian horror theme mixed with the theme of a military base gone with the wind is 5spooky7me. It plays just like doom but it's grittier than doom. I recommend playing it through Proquake  mainly because it comes with mouselook as an option, Doom is meant to be played without mouselook but Quake is definitely meant to be experienced with mouselook. Proquake also comes with them great greaiphics m8.  Quake is a legend and don't bother with the rest of the Quake games. Quake 2 is not a continuation of Quake 1, it's dull, boring, and bad at story telling. Quke 3 arena has been replaced by Quake live which is free. Quake 4 is a continuation of Quake 2 and is the Doom 3 of Quake.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												Quake set the standard as to what a fully 3D first-person shooter should be. Don't let nay-sayers talk smack about the dated graphics, this game's the real experience and after a few minutes soaking up the rich environments you won't even notice anythin but legit awesomeness. The sound design is top of its class, and this game just plain rocks. The original releases used redbook (CD audio) for the ingame soundtrack, so that is impossible to reproduce when selling a digital version of a grame, however this can be easily resolved. Personally I prefer UQE because this engine is extremely vanilla faithful but supports using mod files as the music sources.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2011
												This game is legendary in the FPS genre for good reason. At the time, it was a technical milestone for its superbly impressive 3D engine (which is quite dated, of course), which would later go on to power games like Dark Forces 2: Jedi Knight and Half-Life. It pioneered online multiplayer. It spawned a series of FPS's responsible for defining the genre throughout the 90's and beyond, though Quake 3 is probably the most widely-known of the lot these days. Ultimately, Quake 1 is an insanely fun, action-packed FPS that I can do nothing but recommend to everyone who enjoys the FPS genre. It's both great to see the history of the genre as well as still being an absolute blast to play.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												Do you like/play videogames?Do you like/play First Person Shooters?If the answer to any of those questions is "Yes" then PLAY THIS GAMEQUAKE FREAKING RULES: It is simultaneously the most important PC videogame to ever be released aside from Unreal and Doom, and at the same time one of the most pulse pounding, erection throbbing, masculine pieces of hardcore videogaming to be ever devised.  If you haven't played this game, you can't call yourself a lover of videogames.The story is.... Well WHO GIVES A HORSE?? But in case you want to know what's going on:You are Ranger: A warrior of earth who is sent by the leaders of earth through these ancient portals (Called Slipgates) into other dimentions to retrieve 4 runes and stop the evil overlord Shub-Niggurath that is controlling all the monsters that you fight. The whole story is told through the level design, and from the text and the end of each episode, just to make sure you haven't ran away to burn down your school.The art style is very reminisent of Gothic, Sci-fi, Hell, and the Occult. The whole art style feels like a love letter to the powerful H.P. Lovecraft (if you don't know him, get out and read Cthulu).  Playing Quake feels like being trapped in a metal band's nightmare of awesomness. It's dark, gritty, terrifying, and it just feels wrong. but plays so right. And it should feel like a metal band's nightmare, because Trent Reznor of the band Nine Inch Nails helped ID Software create this masterpiece. He did the amazing music, some of the iconic sound effects, and the voice of Ranger.The level design is SECOND TO NONE: This is as criptic as Doom, and every single map is carefully constructed and planned so that you feel overwhelmed on where you need to go, yet they are simple enough to navigate so that you get the feeling of being a baddass, overcoming the criptic levels. The sheer amount of effort and detail that went into these levels puts every single fps level made today to shame. Even Doom 2016's levels, while criptic and challenging, are childs play compared to the epicness of Quake. The only other games I can think of that have better level design that this are Doom 1 & 2, Heretic/Hexen, Blood, Duke Nukem 3D, and Unreal 1. And even then, I would say that Quake is more complex and better than all of them: the levels are not as straightforward as Dooms, nor as brainkilling as Heretic/Hexens, nor as believable or iconic as Blood or Duke Nukem 3D's; Quake's levels feel like something out of a nightmare and there has been nothing like this ever been seen since.The music in Quake is just simply amazing. It captures the whole mood of being in a nightmare, and is as iconic as Quake it'self. Just listen to this, and it sums up what playing quake is like:


YouTube™ Video: Nine Inch Nails - Quake - Main Theme 

			Views: 824,128		

			This is the main theme from the legendary PC-game Quake, released in 1996, which became a worthy follower of the id-software´s cult Doom.		

The enemies are amazing and very original too: You have to learn and memorise all their attack patterns and behaviours to overcome them, and use the right weapon for the right enemy.The weapons themselves are also metal as ♥♥♥♥: You start off with Ranger's iconic useless Axe, and a fast firing shotgun. There is then the Double barrel shotgun, and the rocket launcher, all stuff you expect. Instead of a machine gun, you have NAILGUNS: a Double barrel nailgun, and a Gattling nail gun, and the nails are not hitscan attacks they are projectiles, so you have to lead your targets. You also get a grenade launcher and a rocket launcher to kill the undead zombies, as they can only be killed by Gibbing them. Finally you have the lightning gun, which requires you to have a line of sight on your enemies to use, so you can't simply use it and duck behind a pillar, meaning you have to THINK on how you will use it.And did I mention this game is hard? FREAKING hard? Even on the easiest difficulty this game will test your skills to the bone. In fact the Nightmare difficulty is so hard that they hid it in the episode select hub. See if you can find it and takkle the ultimate challenge.This is also one of the most important PC games ever made: It was one of the first games to use 3D polygons and run itself off a computers CPU, which was mindboggling for the year 1997. It was the first FPS game to implement the WASD+Mouse controls as standard for FPS, it cemented the fast paced arena deathmatch multiplayer, and it's mindblowing idTech graphics engine created a game engine for HUNDREDS of games to use. So many iconic games today have used this game's engine; Call of Duty, Half-Life, Counter-Strike, the original Team Fortress was a mod for this, and I could go on ALL DAY.Quake is one of the greatest videogames of all time, and the aftershock of it's impact and legecy are STILL being felt to this day. Quake changed videgames forever. 5/5 An unmissable masterpiece.Still not convinced? Watch this:

Install this into your Quake folder in your Steamapps directory file, and you should be good to go!]

content:
Posted: February 12
												By all accords I see the first person shooter genre as something of a terrible plague on mankind. It kills millions and spares no one, its a terrible way to die but this♥♥♥♥♥♥still piles up like Mcrib orders. Its not to say that it doesn’t have its high and lows, but rather its become somewhat of a mainstay in the modern gaming industry, and a quite unwelcome one at that. In fact the industry has a become a breeding ground for generic garbage. To be honest, garbage might be too kind of a word to describe what the genre has devolved into, But that’s a story for another day buckaroo. In the case of early FPS games I can say this much, at least it felt like I was playing a game and not a dribble of cinematic boredom as contrived and cliché as Jar Jar Abrams and his infatuated fan base. But I’m getting ahead of myself as I walk down a path of that I know I cannot return. In the meantime, let us revel in what is the genius of Quake. Quake can probably be best describe as the peculiar case of taking Lovecraft, Heavy metal, and guns galore and mixing it with its own touch of Nine Inch Nail ambiance. I'm no Nine Inch Nail fan but even I can appeciate a good mind♥♥♥♥ that is the soundtrack to this game. However, perhaps that’s what stands out most about Quake… is The Lovecraft worship. No, were not talking about the sorry excuse of a Elric Rip-off style worship imbedded into the Witcher franchise, were talking about a disturbing reimaging of the idea of twisted. A twisted that crawls up your spine and pulls it out while at last laughing in your face spitting your own blood back into your eyes. Yeah a cruel sight, but I would be damned if it didn’t hit the mark and make me ask for seconds. Quake is no different. It doesn’t apologize, it doesn’t hold your hand, and it sure as hell doesn’t slow down so you can duck behind cover and whimper like a little♥♥♥♥♥♥as you wait for the guillotine to chop your sorry♥♥♥♥♥in two. You shouldn't be ducking to save your life you should be blowing your enemies into pieces to save your life. In a time where Iron sights where but a distant idea, and quick action events were nothing more than a way of describing your sex life Quake stood the test of time as a master of its craft. It’s FPS at its best, with no compromises and no Bull$*&#. You want filler, well take that crap back to anime and give it a resounding middle finger while your at it because that doesn’t exist here. This is pure mayhem and death like never before all in its own twisted world to boot. It's not here to pour out the horrors of war or to make you feel for someone its here to blast you away like a good Bolt Thrower riff. I didn't ask for a melodrama I asked for a damn game, and Quake gave that and more. To say that this is a doom clone would be a little bit of wrong misrepresentation of what is otherwise a ground breaking game in not just the FPS genre but in 3D gaming at large. I’m not here to give a history lesson but to be frank with you, this game deserves more than just praise. Quake expanded the graph from being purely horizontal to being horizontal, vertical and misdirectional (if ever that was a word) without taking a second to stop and say “well my works done here lets hit the can…”. Yeah, enjoyed the most recent entry in the Doom series (Doom 4) then you can thank Quake (and Id software who HELPED make the recent DOOM) for making what is practically an identical experience. Let’s be honest, Doom needed a little Quake to take it out of its primordial roots. No shame in what Doom started as but a facelift didn’t hurt this Hollywood failure from getting a deserving reboot. In short, Quake is to FPS what Judas Priest is to metal. It’s the ♥♥♥♥ing embodiment of FPS at its best. I couldn’t recommend this game more. Between the twisted creatures, the atmospheric environment, and a soundtrack that even Penderecki would smile in glee and lube up for... this game was FPS heaven, before cliché after anime level cliché took over the industry and Metal Gear Solid was praised as the second coming of gamer christ we had Quake. Praise the high fathers of whatever mad studio (Id studio) had the balls to do what most couldn't, make a great FPS! Sadly, we have yet to get a proper sequel to this game, and it doesn’t look promising in the future. But hell, it doesn’t stop you from going and getting this damn game. If I have any criticism of the steam version it would be simple… “Where the hell is the soundtrack?” I mean I understand copyrights a ♥♥♥♥♥, but how hard is it really to get such a thing done, I shouldn’t feel the need to make it an addition to the game but such is life. If it isn’t already obvious get this game… Better yet, get the real version of this game and enjoy you what FPS could, and should be.This is MasterOfThePit calling…“Praise to Deus Ex and praise Kek...Out”

content:
Posted: February 13, 2012
												There's not much I can say about Quake you haven't heard elsewhere. It's fun, it's dark, it's immersive, and it firmly established many of the conventions of FPS gaming we now take for granted. There would be no Team Fortress 2 without Quake, and that is why I wield the Original with pride. Id Software may have moved on to bigger things with Rage, but plans for Doom 4 make me believe that a new Quake may lurk somewhere beyond the horizon. It's important to know your roots in gaming, and while I got my online start in Starsiege: Tribes, my favorite singleplayer FPS of yore was probably Quake, if not Half-Life. Quake gave me my love of shotguns and grenade launchers and if an FPS cannot deliver me satisfying examples of such, then it does not measure up to my expectations for what constitutes adequate firepower. You can keep your assault rifles, throwing knives and tactical nukes. Give me a little buckshot and a little boom, and I will give you delicious interdimensional demon gibs.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 8, 2015
												It may be fairly short (even though I'm sure Doom 2 was a comparable length, Quake just seems to go by quicker), but isn't that much better than wishing it were over sooner? Every episode I finished had me smiling with glee, while at the same time feeling regretful that I was that much closer to finishing it. Isn't that a definitive description of a fantastic game? Make no mistake, Quake came out in 1996, and while it may not hold a candle to modern games graphics-wise, it still has aged EXTREMELY well. Once you get the graphics and keymapping set up to your liking, you'll be caught up in the dark, bloody, violent, gruesome, and AWESOME explosion that is Quake. What other game takes elements from sci-fi, fantasy, some oddball Doom-esque religion, and H.P. LOVECRAFT?If you're looking for a game with tight controls, fast gameplay, creepy atmosphere, intense firefights, and GREAT music/ambience, then you've been looking for Quake.A note about the music:Due to the way the music was integrated into the original game (playing off the game CD in the drive), the Steam version does NOT include ANY music in the game. Luckily, there's a patch someone made, named "Ultimate Quake", that installs all the original music at the appropriate levels and times!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2016
												What's there to say? Quake is one of the earliest First Person Shooters with a fully 3D world, items, and enemies. It hasn't aged quite as well as Doom in my opinion, but don't let that discourage you, quake knows what it is doing, and does it well. This game still stands as one of the most solid FPS experiences ever made, laying the foundation for many future games in the genre. Quake plays similar to most of the original FPS games, you run around at a fast pace killing monsters, finding secrets, and collecting keys. It features the classic arsenal of shotguns, nailguns (basically machine guns), rocket launchers and more. The enemies and locations follow a medieval/dark magic theme, with a few futuristic settings here and there. This theme is pretty unique and isn't used for any of the sequels, in fact I'd go so far as to say that this game never got a true sequel. The game's music was originally played from the disc so you will need to get a patch somewhere if you want it (The soundtrack was made by nine inch nails, it's worth your time).There are some notable issues with the game however. I would not recommend playing the game as is when purchased. Go find a community made source port or patch, because it's not set up well for modern systems. It also crashes on rare occasions. One big issue is a bug involving runes. Quake has four runes which you must collect to enter the final area of the game, said runes will occasionally disappear when changing levels or respawning, this causes you to need to redo an entire episode of the game to get them back. The good news is that you can avoid this by making some extra backup saves here and there.If you are looking for a classic key collecting and monster gibbing experience, then pick this sucker up and rocket jump to victory.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												Created on the heels of the runaway success of the Doom series, Quake paved the way for the first-person shooter with its fast-paced action and graphical advancements. Fully realized 3D graphics resulted in some of the most intricate and well-designed maps in the genre's history. The feeling of running around the various honeycombed shortcuts is an unmatched satisfaction in FPS movement. Each map is made eye-catching and memorable by the game's distinct artstyle which draws from a fusion of medieval and metallic. The same can be said for the game's enemy roster, which range from laser rifle-lugging shock troopers to muscle-bound bundles of teeth and claws. Unfortunately the base game doesn't take full advantage of the diversity of its enemies, with later levels sinking into the tedium of firing shotgun shell after shotgun shell into ogres and death-knights. This is rectified somewhat by the higher difficulties, which see no problem in pitting unrealistic numbers against the player. Quake is an addicting and wonderful game at any price, and it's worth owning to understand what makes this game such a solid pillar of the genre. Now let's hope they don't give this an ill-fitting modern reboot as well...If you want to improve your experience check out some of the community guides on how to implement things like different engines and the soundtrack. The base Steam release is unfortunately lacking in some areas, and the work getting in fixes can be well worth the effort.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2011
												This is still after all these years the game I run to when I need to have fun.  ID still pretty much owns the genre of "I just want to kill everything with this giant gun, flick a switch, find a key, find a new gun, and kill some more."  I still love Doom, Wolfenstein, and the rest of the Quake series; but playing the original Quake - with Trent Reznor's awesome soundtrack pumping behind the cacophony of explosions, zombie moans and chainsaw wails - takes me right back to the summer when the demo came out (THANK YOU PC GAMER) and my father and I ran to the store that night to buy a computer fast enough to play it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 8, 2015
												It may be fairly short (even though I'm sure Doom 2 was a comparable length, Quake just seems to go by quicker), but isn't that much better than wishing it were over sooner? Every episode I finished had me smiling with glee, while at the same time feeling regretful that I was that much closer to finishing it. Isn't that a definitive description of a fantastic game? Make no mistake, Quake came out in 1996, and while it may not hold a candle to modern games graphics-wise, it still has aged EXTREMELY well. Once you get the graphics and keymapping set up to your liking, you'll be caught up in the dark, bloody, violent, gruesome, and AWESOME explosion that is Quake. What other game takes elements from sci-fi, fantasy, some oddball Doom-esque religion, and H.P. LOVECRAFT?If you're looking for a game with tight controls, fast gameplay, creepy atmosphere, intense firefights, and GREAT music/ambience, then you've been looking for Quake.A note about the music:Due to the way the music was integrated into the original game (playing off the game CD in the drive), the Steam version does NOT include ANY music in the game. Luckily, there's a patch someone made, named "Ultimate Quake", that installs all the original music at the appropriate levels and times!

content:
Posted: June 2, 2014
												A good shooter from the 90s, with graphics that are a little (ok, VERY) dated now, but with good sound design in terms of overall presentation. Actually, speaking of presentation, this game has a large quantity of brown and grey, and does seem a little ugly. But it's a part of the style, so I won't complain. The gameplay (being the most important) is what you'd expect from a shooter, but the locales and enemies keep it interesting. The difficulty is varried, but fair given that you can use quicksaves/quickloads. Again, no complaints on this front, What I will complain about is the story, it's a hodge-podge of vague text boxes jammed in your face before and after every level that I don't even remember half of. But the game doesn't really suffer for it, the gameplay is what we're all here for, and like I said, it's fun and functional to play, and I definitely recomend it... unless you're bothered by dated grapics.8.5/10

content:
Posted: July 3, 2011
												released by id Software on June 22, 1996, Quake was programmed by John Carmack, Michael Abrash and John Cash. The level and scenarios were designed by American McGee, Sandy Petersen, John Romero and Tim Willits. The graphics were designed by Adrian Carmack, Kevin Cloud. Music and sound design was by Trent Reznor of Nine Inch Nails fame.The game engine developed for Quake, the Quake engine, popularized several major advances in the 3D game genre: polygonal models instead of prerendered sprites; full 3D level design instead of a 2.5D map; prerendered lightmaps; and allowing end users to partially program the game (in this case with QuakeC), which popularized fan-created modifications (mods).

content:
Posted: July 24, 2015
												Do i really need to tell you how good it is ?I won't talk about how important this game was to gaming as a whole, with it's innovative, revolutionary, previously unseen tech  and addictive, genre defining, balanced multiplayer that created a stone solid community which is still strong today, and united gamers around the globe.But i think, because of all that, it's singleplayer was overshadowed and somewhat underrated, it has best fps design i have seen in a game to date. Yes i know you may say: -But, Duke nukem 3d...  and to that i say: -no, i am sorry, it's not even close. This game is atmospheric, to the degree that it would make Lovecraft proud. The soundtrack is creepy, and if fully immerse into this world, it's so unworldly it becomes scary, i am genuinely terrified and scared when i play the game, not that it has jumpscares, it barely does, there's something sinister about everything surrounding you. Help...And yes i see, the state steam sells this game is terrible, but please Download Quke ultimate patch, it resolves all the issues, at least it worked perfectly for me. you should find it in web or steam guides. Yes it even fixes soundtrack. 9/10 one of best shooters, much, MUCH better than duke nukem 3d and/or Quake 2.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
												Quake.If you’re here, the odds that you know what Quake is are pretty significant, so this review might seem a little (or quite a bit) pointless.But, Quake has a special meaning to me – Quake and I go way back, it being one of the first games I would ever play, along with Half-life and Doom. I still remember those days, zipping around those moody corridors and those dank, decrepit hallways, filling everything that moved with as many rounds as my 6-year-old hands were able to pump out... Before inevitably dying at the hands of some monstrosity, of course.Sure, I wasn’t good at it by any conceivable degree, but damn, I still loved it. It was more than just a game to me, the environment, the enemy design – it all came together to create an experience that I just can’t seem to dig out of my head, not that I would ever want to. Even now, I still feel that urge to boot it up and shoot something.I can’t promise that your time with Quake will be anything similar to mine, and you may find it to be dated, uninteresting or dull (and, in my opinion NONE of those things can define Quake). But to me, Quake will always be there, flashing through the back of my mind, making me feel the same way about it as I did 12 years ago, and because of that, I have no choice but to recommend it.

												A true classic FPS. It's a must play for anywone who has played a game with a first person camera. Sure, the graphics are ugly and envirements suffer from "BROWN SYNDROME". If you look past that though you find amazing enemy designs and places. There is nothing like shooting lovercraftian monsters in a gothic castle. The combat is fast-paced like DOOM. No wimpy cover systems here! Each enemy is dynamic and intresting. Giant monsters with only a mouth and brutal claws that shoot lighting, to leaping monsters who jump at your face. Sadly, the weapons are weak. That does make each enemy intimidating though. 10/10 MUST PLAY

												If you like FPS games  you owe it to yourself to play Quake.  Quake pulled off a few firsts in FPS games.First truly 3d.First Team Fortress Mod.First true professional gaming scene.First true Capture The Flag.The list goes on and on.  The game is still played professionally, has live servers, dedicated fans, and has been updated constantly with new content and improved visuals by the player and fan base.  And after all these year still remains the fastest and most demanding death match game ever produced.  It's younger sibling Quake 3 coming in a close second.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												If you like FPS games  you owe it to yourself to play Quake.  Quake pulled off a few firsts in FPS games.First truly 3d.First Team Fortress Mod.First true professional gaming scene.First true Capture The Flag.The list goes on and on.  The game is still played professionally, has live servers, dedicated fans, and has been updated constantly with new content and improved visuals by the player and fan base.  And after all these year still remains the fastest and most demanding death match game ever produced.  It's younger sibling Quake 3 coming in a close second.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												Thanks, valve germany for letting me write this.Quake is id software's other FPS giant that co-created the online-FPS with all its beloved tropes. Quake offers four episodes of fast-paced, exploration based, pre-2000s FPS-glory. Despite its grim, colourless visuals, Quake plays in a much more engaging way than modern products of the genre, with its medieval/lovecraftian inspired style and ambience coupled with fast-paced movement and gunplay, it can be easily classified as a 3D Doom.However, like Doom, Quake was originally meant to be run on MS-DOS, so you might require a source port for a more convenient (or let alone executable) experience. My biggest recommendation would be the darkplaces engine, you can download it for Quake 1 as well as its expansions in this link http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=1756923Quake remains one of the most popular retro-FPS games for good reasons, it still holds up as a fun and challenging arena shooter for both singleplayer and multiplayer.It's basically Deathmatch Classic if it had a singleplayer and a right to exist.And yes you ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, this is where Kindergarten Fortress 2 came from.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
												I hard to figure out what should I say now... This is old game, original debuted in 22nd June, 1996.  I guess those players have bought this game who have played this game before, and now they are enjoying nostalgia. For the same reason I bought this game.  About the game: The gameplay is really simple; collect guns and ammos, shoot at anything, find the exit.  But, why did I recommend this game? Because of the atmosphere! This game has an atmosphere what I have not seen in others game yet. The sounds, the design and the silent mysterious. I think those things gives that great atmosphere to the Quake universe.  I advice if you are thinking to buy this game, see a few gameplay video of Quake. Good things: -Mystery atmosphere. -Simple gameplay. -It has online and local Co-op mod.  Bad thing: -Only a few hours gameplay. (in single-player mod) -The game does not include original musics. (you can solve this, read below)  Solve music issue: If you need the original music and little bit better graphic quality, then you must download and install [Ultimate Quake Patch].  


Ultimate Quake Patch 
A Guide for Quake
By: MOOK

			This patch utilizes the DarkPlaces engine developed by LordHavoc, the plasmagun fix by OoPpEe, the music patch originally hosted on widescreengamingforum.com and the NSIS install system developed by Nullsoft.		


Only one thing bad! After you installed this patch you must disable the Steam-overlay on this game, otherwise the game will be frozen.  I recommend this game those who want a lazy gameplay for a few hours and those who want a little bit nostalgia.  P.S. I apologies of the Quake fans for my review have not been absolute positive. I wanted to be objective.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												The king... no, the GOD of first person shooters! This is the genre-defining, timeless masterpiece of a game that was released back in 1996. The first true 3D engine, amazing music track, horrifying monster sounds, unrivaled smooth gameplay, complex level designs, do I need to say more? You choose a difficulty and get right into the action! A must play for everyone.Oh and kids, THIS is what a FPS is. Don't get fooled by the unfortunate mistakes that are called "games" nowadays.P.S. There are some mods that drastically improve the graphics, and since the game is very old, some users might want to take advantage of those, even if only to play on HD resolutions. But I am sure anyone can enjoy this classic even in its purest form.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												Doom's Big Brother.This is the heavy hitter of id Software's library. Quake is an evolution not just for FPS games, but games as a medium.In Quake, you fight through 4 episodes of Adrenaline pumping action, much like Doom, albeit with a much much MUCH darker atmosphere. The game is quite a lot faster than Doom, with Speedrunning being quite popular with the game. Gameplay remains unchanged from Doom. You move through the levels, killing everything in your path, then leaving via exit. The game doesn't have many bosses, only really 2 (End of Episode 1 and the Final Boss), but the encounters are memorable. The enemies are all interesting, and frightening, with such enemies as the giant Shambler, Ogres that hurl grenades at you, and Fiends that claw you into bits.The maps are inspired by several dark fantasy influences, notably that of H. P. Lovecraft; most notably, the end boss of the first episode is named Chthon, and the final boss is named Shub-N iggurath, although there is little resemblance to the original literary descriptions. Some levels have Lovecraftian names as well, such as the Vaults of Zin or the Ebon Fortress. The original Quake runs on DOSBox, but you have the option to run GLQuake. Regardless of which version you want to play, make sure you look for source-ports, such as Quake Epsilon, or FTEQW to name a few to play the game at its max potential. The games soundtrack ran off of red book cd, so look for the Ultimate Quake patch as well if you want the great soundtrack as well (100% must install.) Also look for multiplayer source ports as well because the Quake community, like the Doom community, is still alive and kicking.Quake is as great as Doom is, with darker tones, and faster gameplay. If you enjoyed Doom, or just wanna play an arcadey fps, Quake is the game for you.

content:
Posted: March 2
												Quake is a FPS game made by id software and released in 1996. it stood put among the FPS or "Doom Clones" at the time for a few notable reasons. It was fully 3D, had smooth animations at complex (for its time) level design. But how does it hold up? How does it play for a first time player? The awnser to both is amazingly well.Game:The game is set across 4 different dimensions. This causes each of the four episodes to have its own unique location. The weapons are plentifull and fun to use. The line-up includes grenade launchers, nail guns and a lightning gun. The only problem I had with the game was the two bossfights. They didn't require shooting, but pressing buttons. You may have to shoot you way to the buttons, but the bosses themselves doesn't require one bullet to kill, which really sucks. The games difficulty is on the heavy side. I played on normal and found the difficulty what I would expect on hard with other games. Respect to the people finding nightmare enjoyable and finishable..Technical:The game works out of the box with the steam version, but there are a few issues. The controls are not as smooth as modern FPS games. The soundtrack ran off a cd, that means no soundtrack for the steam version. the resolution is really low (Doesn't bother me but can bother you). To fix all three issues mentiones above (The only technical complaints I had) I used the Ultimate quake patch. It uses the DarkPlaces engine developed by LordHavoc, the plasmagun fix by OoPpEe, the music patch originally hosted on widescreengamingforum.com and the NSIS install system by Nullsoft. The Ultimate Quake Patch was compiled by (as I understand it) MenaceInc.I would highly recommend this game to ANYONE!!P.S. Don't forget to download episode 5. Its calles DOPA and was developed by Machine Games (Who did a amazing job with Wolfenstein the New Order and Wolfenstein the Old Blood) for quakes 20th birthday. It has te same old school design and if it was included with the original game, I wouldnt have know that it wasn't id that made this episode.I can't think of higher praise for DOPA. Get it if you get Quake. It was released for free. To install it you just have to create a dopa folder where quake is instelled, extract the zipfile in the folder and double click the batch file.

If you enjoyed Doom, or just wanna play an arcadey fps, Quake is the game for you.

												Hi kids! My name is Quake! Now I recokon some of you youngsters don't know me by name, but you've played me at some point in your life. Team Fortress? I gave it life. Half-Life? It was built on my bones. Capture the flag? It was here first sonny! Yup, I'm pretty much the grandaddy of fast paced deathmatching and fragging your friends over the internet, why back in my day we had Quakeworld and that Gamespy thing those kids seem to love so much used to be called Q-spy! That's right! A whole industry sprang up around me! And now look at you kids and yer gosh darned military shooters! Yer precious hats and yer ingame stores! All them fancy graphics and DLCs! But you go on! You have a good ol time! I'll be here, I'm always here because good games never die, they just fade away.....

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 4, 2016
												Awesomeness in 5 letters :)Here is a more updated review, as requested by Butane:Note: I had to cut my review, most notably at the end, because apparently Steam only allows so many text. That is the reason there is no modding and sourceports 'chapter' are limited. Sorry for that.Quake is a first person shooter or FPS developed by id software, released in 1996.Originally planned to be released way earlier (it was mentioned in Commander Keen as a follow up) aimed to be a Magic&Melee type of game. The name for the game came from the protagonists name, Quake.Quake was presented as "The most dangerous person on the continent, wielding a hammer of Thunderbolts, a Ring of Regeneration and a trans dimensional Artifact, fighting for justice"This idea was later scrapped for a more 'id software' approach, which is of course, an FPS.Quake's development was rough. Because of the 3D technology they were going for, it took John Carmack a full year to make the engine. What didn't help either was the release of games like Duke Nukem 3D, which used the Build engine, a very advanced 2.5D engine for its time. Carmack wasn't impressed by it though.When the engine was finally finished, the guys at id could finally work on the game. Sadly, the tensions were high and lots of work was wasted. So was originally a Dragon planned and a lot of other stuff. John Romero was absent a lot as well. This resulted in John Romero being fired from id after the game was released.In short, the game was rushed.In Quake, you play as a character named Ranger. Quake is the codename for an unknown enemy using slipgates (fancy word for teleporters) to send all sorts of monsters to earth. As a part of a special forces team, you have to use the slipgates to travel to Quake and kill him! Only problem here being, your team is killed off quickly and you are the only one left to fight. You have to collect 4 runes, 1 in each episode, to open a slipgate to the final boss. Thats the story in a nutshell.The gameplay is similar to previous id titles. Kill bad guys, find secrets and keys, collect supplies and exit the level. Simple stuff. After 7 levels, you have the final level where you can collect a rune, resulting in a bossfight and the exit to the level opens once you've defeated the boss. Each episode has a secret level as well. But while in Doom you could have 10 or more enemies on screen, with the new 3D engine every monsters is fully 3D. This had a large impact on performance. So in Quake you have a maximal of 5, maybe 10 enemies on screen. To compensate for this, most weapons are a lot weaker. (Than say, Dooms weapons)Speaking about weapons, you have 7 to choose from:The Axe, Shotgun, Double Barreled Shotgun, Nailgun, Supernailgun, Grenade Launcher, Rocket Launcher and Thunderbolt.- The axe is your basic melee weapon. Does little damage against enemies but has unlimited 'ammo'.- The shotgun is your basic hitscan ranged weapon. It fires 6 pellets, doing 4 damage each. It can kill a basic grunt in 2 shots and a dog 1 one shot. Uses shells.You spawn with the shotgun, axe, 100 hp and 25 shells when you start a new game and in multiplayer.- The super or double barreled shotgun is a better shotgun. Uses 2 shells and does more damage, but only effective on close range (whilst in basic shotgun has pretty good range)- The nailgun is a projectile based weapon, firing nails (duh) rapidly. It can be seen as your basic machine gun. Uses nails.- The supernailgun is the nailguns bigger brother. It has a higher firerate, does more damage and uses 2 nails for 1 shot.- The grenade launcher need no explanation. Oddly enough, it uses rockets for ammo.- The rocket launcher is pretty self explanatory, just like the grenade launcher. Uses rockets.- The Thunderbolt is the games most powerful weapon. Being a gun that shoots out lightning, it uses cells as ammo and can even kill the biggest foes in a matter of seconds. As a counter to this power, cells are pretty rare and pickups yield only few cells. Warning: don't fire this thing underwater, its totally.. Lets say, ridiculous.To spice up the gameplay, you have so called powerups. These are items that last a short time and give you a benefit.Powerups are:Quad damage. 4 times the damage for 30 seconds for every weapon. Gibbing time!Ring of shadows: invisible for 30 seconds. Sneak past monsters and players alike!Biosuit: with this, you can swim in slime without harm and it provides oxygen underwater as well. Lasts 30 seconds.Pentagram of protection. Invulnerable to any incoming damage for 30 seconds.Other powerups include armor, ammo and keycards.But what are these weapons and powerups worth when you have no bad guys to shoot? Luckily, there are plenty. I'll go over them really quickly, I promise :)Rottfish. Piranha on steroids.Rottweiler. Annoying dog.Grunt. Basic soldier.Enforcer. Basic soldier Mk. 2Zombie. You can't kill the undead, but you sure can blow it into giblets!Ogre. Uses a chainsaw Evil Dead style and wield a grenade launcher.Scrag. Floating enemy that shoots projectiles.Spawn. Slimey, jumping thing that explodes when it is killed. Episode 4 exclusive.Knight. Uses a sword.Death knight. Knights bigger brother. Comes with a projectile based attack as well.Fiend. Leaps toward you to use his sickles upclose.Vore. Mutated spider that launches homing rockets.Shambler. Big♥♥♥♥♥guy that has a lighting and melee attack.There are two bosses as well, which I'm not going to spoil :)Quake offers 4 episodes from the get go. Each episode has 8 levels, making for a total of 32 levels. (Final boss level and introduction level not counted)When you start a new game, you start off in the introduction level. It offers 3 slipgates, offering 3 difficulty levels. Easy, Normal and Hard. There is a 4th difficulty, Nightmare, but it is hidden in the episode selection.Selecting a difficulty leads you to the episode selection. From there you can select 1 of 4 slipgates to play that episode. After a episode is completed, that particular slipgate is locked off, meaning you completed it, since you collected the Rune.The first levels of each episode are the easiest levels. You start off in a military base with low level enemies like Rottweilers, Grunts and Enforcers. These levels are often my personal favorites, since you can see they put the most effort in them. (And I just enjoy fighting the soldiers.)After you completed all episodes, and thus collected all the runes, the gate to the final boss opens.One thing Quake is really well known for are the sounds and the soundtracks. When Doom came out, the band Nine Inch Nails got addicted to playing Doom. When they heard of Quake, Trent Reznor wanted to do work for id.He did created a lot of sounds and the legendary soundtrack. His sounds range from the voices of the grunts to the pickup sound for armor.Quake's soundtrack is really unique. It offers a more ambient horror theme than the usual id metal. With Quake being a dark and gritty game, this really sets the mood.Its hard to describe this on paper, but I suggest you go and play Quake or listen to its soundtrack at night. Back in the day, this really made people ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ their pants whilst playing.Note: Quakes soundtrack does not come with the Steam version, since it ran off an CD. Don't fear though, there are tons of patches for the soundtrack. A quick Google search will do the job. SourceportsTo run Quake on a more modern system a sourceport is recommended. I use DirectQ personally.Quake didn't became big for its singleplayer. It was the multiplayer that really gave Quake its legacy. I'm not going to go really deep into the multiplayer, since I mostly played singleplayer. Sorry :/TL:DR:Quake, a great game for its time and even nowadays. Rushed, but still very impressive. A classic id software title thats really worth picking up!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												10/10this game is so well designed I was really surprised, because I played it in 2014 for the first time and didnt expected this level of quality. Everything in this game makes sense and fits very well, there isnt much you could take out without killing the experience. Every weapon has its place and situation where its good at (except the weak nailgun, but since you loose all your weapons every new episode you still use it).I especially like how the guns feel. The shotgun for example has this deep sound with a quiet click sound after it and when you hit enemys with it they make a sound and cancel their attack. This makes the gun feel like you really shoot something and hurt the enemys. I cant really describe it.The levels look similar but thats because of the age of the game, they still look interesting and dont get boring.The soundtrack is extremely well and isnt some random metal music like in Quake 2 but only atmosspheric music which really fits the game and sometimes even creeped the ♥♥♥♥ out of me.ATTENTION: The game doesnt come with the soundtrack, install the Ultimate Quake Patch which not only fixes the music but also improves graphics and animation quality.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
												Trent Reznor.....not that it matters mind you. There is no music included with the Steam Version.Amazing, fast paced, run-and-gun FPS gameplay from the mid-90s. An ID software classic with awe inspiring gothic theme. Quake is all about an invasion of Earth by Shub-Niggurath (a cthulhu like being which resembles a Dark Young) via a series of slipgates created by humanity in an attempt to create teleportation technology. A lot like DOOM when you get right down to it. This is Gothic though, DOOM was more or less......well hellspawn. Without this game there would be no Half Life or Call of Duty. Period.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												What I like about the very first Quake is its very gothic and satanic, its as satanic as Doom where you fight demons and monsters from hell. Its very similar, but the difficulty is not that hard like Doom. But i do like the movement in the game. Highest difficulty (nightmare, which is a secret mode), will only increase enemy speed movement and reaction, life damage should be the same (i think, or it may add more damage). What i know for sure, they dont respawn after killing them, so if you are smart on tactics, you should be able to find a way to find a room to take a breather from all the pressure on killing, unlike Doom where in highest difficulty you have little chance to breathe from, and dont have much time.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 2, 2014
												     This game is the base of every modern FPS. This game was revolutionary for many reasons. One of these is the amazing Team Fortress mod (which I still play to this day), also its engine was the same base engine of all gold source games (Day of Defeat, Half-Life, TFC, and more), plus this game was one of the first FPS, and one of the first to have online multiplayer. I might not of played Quake "back in the day" but I can tell that it is still a amazing FPS and more people need to rejoin its amazing online multiplayer. I highly support this game and belive it is a gold mine of gaming history.-John

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2016
												- Note that I've played at least 10 hours via a launcher that doesn't add to Steam playtime -I never played the original Quake until I got it this year so I don't have the whole nostalgia thing but even so this is it, when action games had effort put into actually making them fun and engaging with actual areas to explore and decisions to make before becoming more about hand-holding and empty spectacle.There's some weird stuff like the Super Shotgun and Nailgun just being flat upgrades of the non-supers and hit detection with some enemy attacks being a bit off, but...that's kind of it. Sure it's simple but everything works so well. This is a damn good shooter far better than most despite being two decades old now. The age sort of works to its advantage in a way, it can run on just about anything, there's a good number of levels in the main game and a history of loads of mods and maps, with people making more even today. Machine Games who did the awesome Wolfenstein reboot actually made a free level pack recently which is pretty kickass.Every fan of action games, especially those who've mostly only played recent ones should play this.

Quake is all about an invasion of Earth by Shub-Niggurath (a cthulhu like being which resembles a Dark Young) via a series of slipgates created by humanity in an attempt to create teleportation technology. A lot like DOOM when you get right down to it. This is Gothic though, DOOM was more or less......well hellspawn. Without this game there would be no Half Life or Call of Duty. Period.

												What I like about the very first Quake is its very gothic and satanic, its as satanic as Doom where you fight demons and monsters from hell.
