content:
Posted: June 2, 2014
												     This game is the base of every modern FPS. This game was revolutionary for many reasons. One of these is the amazing Team Fortress mod (which I still play to this day), also its engine was the same base engine of all gold source games (Day of Defeat, Half-Life, TFC, and more), plus this game was one of the first FPS, and one of the first to have online multiplayer. I might not of played Quake "back in the day" but I can tell that it is still a amazing FPS and more people need to rejoin its amazing online multiplayer. I highly support this game and belive it is a gold mine of gaming history.-John

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2016
												- Note that I've played at least 10 hours via a launcher that doesn't add to Steam playtime -I never played the original Quake until I got it this year so I don't have the whole nostalgia thing but even so this is it, when action games had effort put into actually making them fun and engaging with actual areas to explore and decisions to make before becoming more about hand-holding and empty spectacle.There's some weird stuff like the Super Shotgun and Nailgun just being flat upgrades of the non-supers and hit detection with some enemy attacks being a bit off, but...that's kind of it. Sure it's simple but everything works so well. This is a damn good shooter far better than most despite being two decades old now. The age sort of works to its advantage in a way, it can run on just about anything, there's a good number of levels in the main game and a history of loads of mods and maps, with people making more even today. Machine Games who did the awesome Wolfenstein reboot actually made a free level pack recently which is pretty kickass.Every fan of action games, especially those who've mostly only played recent ones should play this.

												amazing and timeless game, but I recommend playing it on a sourceport (see: community hub guides, they'll explain everything for you) instead of the winquake or quakegl executables that come with the game. Multiplayer servers are still active, although I'd recommend nQuake/ezQuake for the best possible experience there. Lastly, if you go to the quaddicted website you can find some really amazing custom campaigns that modders still release up to this day. I've spent about 10x as many hours on this game as my steam hours show because playing some of the sourceports won't log your hours on steam, and after all that time spent I can honestly say this game is tons of fun even today

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												I have to admit, this game's starting to grow on me.That doesn't mean I'm ignoring it's flaws though.The BadFirst of all, because of the game's poor optimization for modern PCs, you have to set the resolution EVERY.  TIME.  YOU START THE GAME.  And the max resolution is only 1280 x 720.  Also, to enable the ability to look vertically and diagonally, you have to press ` to enter the game console and type in "+Mlook" and to get the crosshair back, you'll have to type in "Crosshair 1".  Again, you have to do this EVERY.  TIME.  YOU ENTER THE GAME.This port also does not come with the game's soundtrack which many people are♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off about, BUT honestly I think this is a good thing.  The atmosphere is impressive and honestly the lack of soundtrack really brings that out.  And while the soundtrack is amazing, I still say that the game is better off without it.  It just doesn't really fit in for me.Also, there's something I have against the enemies and weapons.  Whilst there is a lot of them and they are rather entertaining, the game seems to have a strong habit of constantly throwing fat shreks with chainsaws and grenade launchers in literally every corridor, and it gets really samey and repetetive at times. With the weapons, I can't help but feel like some of them are completely worthless.  For instance, you start out with the shotgun on level 1, and you progress onto level 2 and all of a sudden you have the Double-Barrel shotgun, which is basically Quake's faster version of DOOM 2's Super Shotgun which immediately renders the normal shotgun completely worthless.  Some would argue that DOOM 2 did the exact same thing yet I disagree; the normal shotgun in DOOM 2 had much more range compared to the Super Shotgun and still did a decent amount of damage, but the shotgun in Quake becomes completely forgettable with it's apaulling amount of damage against most enemies in the game.  Hell, the exact same thing happens for The Nailgun and the Grenade Launcher!  They all get replaced by more powerful copies of their own self, a la the Super Nailgun and the Rocket Launcher.  This was just my thoughts on it though, you guys probably completely disagree with me.  I just feel as though they could have made some of the weapons in the game actually worth something and not have to be thrown away as completely useless later on.And what the ♥♥♥♥ is the story?  Am I just some dude in some weird places killing random living creatures native to the area because he's a psychopath who enjoys blood, gore and murder?  Until you lot give me the full story, that's what I'm going with.Also, the graphics occasionally give me headaches.  Just sayin'.The Good♥♥♥♥♥♥/div>Right, I like the gunplay, it feels really great.  Actually, the combat in general is really satisfying (minus the melee weapon, the axe) through and through.  The enemy design is really creative, especially for the zombies and each map, despite all having the same atmosphere, all feels unique and different.Like I said, the atmosphere is brilliant.Also, that ♥♥♥♥ing Shambler.  The ♥♥♥♥ing shambler.  Scary af.So overall, despite having ♥♥♥♥ loads of flaws as of today, Quake still remains to be a fun game and of moderate challenge.6/10Still though,

content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												Judging from single-player alone, the game is a typical id shooter but it was more of a tech show for John Carmack and team's highly sophisticated new 3d engine. Multiplayer is still alive in some circles and I can see why. The weapons are the least interesting aspects when compared to Doom and Heretic but atmosphere, level design (be proud John Romero) and sound are top notch for their time. If you like shooters and don't mind the dated graphics, this is a classic well worth playing. Just don't expect anything TOO epic here.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												And... lightning does in fact strike the same place twice.If you like, you could just read my DOOM review, swapping the word QUAKE for DOOM. But that wouldn't be fair.iD managed to produce another industry changer, a scant three years after DOOM was released. Whereas DOOM brought 3D gaming to the masses and made multiplayer something that people felt should be included as standard, QUAKE raised the bar even higher.PC Gamer certainly helped QUAKE along, thanks to including the shareware episode on their coverdisc. So those people not lucky enough to have fast internet access could still join in the fun.I think at the time, QUAKE was even more of a global sensation than DOOM was, but with hindsight I think it's fair to say that DOOM shook things up more than QUAKE did. But only just. A lot of QUAKE's legacy is thanks to the addons and patches which quickly followed the main game.QUAKE proved that smooth, fluid, entirely polygon-based games were feasible and practical. Suddenly, all the sprite-based FPS games that were being released looked incredibly dated. Not their fault - nobody but iD saw it coming. Duke Nukem 3D had been released just one month before iD pushed their tech demo out into the world, and everybody knew something big was coming.If DOOM made multiplayer gaming on company LANs the next big thing, then QUAKE made internet deathmatches the in-thing. Quakeworld which followed later on in the year greatly improved and streamlined this service so even those with dial-up connections could participate.GLQuake greatly improved the graphics for those lucky few who had these new-fangled 3D accelerator cards - suddenly everybody was buying Matrox and Voodoo cards just to play the new, improved QUAKE.And if people thought DOOM was expandable, QUAKE blew their minds. Not only could you make levels, you could make new models, new sound and music, and even rewrite parts of the code to make entirely new games (QUAKE Chess anybody?)Personally, QUAKE is not my favourite FPS. Not by a long shot. I don't think I ever even finished the single-player campaign. But I can't deny it's influence, and it is amazing to see what they did with the hardware at the time.

content:
Posted: March 20
												As an enlightened, modern parent, I try to be as involved as possible in the lives of my six children. I encourage them to join team sports. I attend their teen parties with them to ensure no drinking or alcohol is on the premises. I keep a fatherly eye on the CDs they listen to and the shows they watch, the company they keep and the books they read. You could say I'm a model parent. My children have never failed to make me proud, and I can say without the slightest embellishment that I have the finest family in the USA. Two years ago, my wife Carol and I decided that our children's education would not be complete without some grounding in modern computers. To this end, we bought our children a brand new Compaq to learn with. The kids had a lot of fun using the handful of application programs we'd bought, such as Adobe's Photoshop and Microsoft's Word, and my wife and I were pleased that our gift was received so well. Our son Peter was most entranced by the device, and became quite a pro at surfing the net. When Peter began to spend whole days on the machine, I became concerned, but Carol advised me to calm down, and that it was only a passing phase. I was content to bow to her experience as a mother, until our youngest daughter, Cindy, charged into the living room one night to blurt out: "Peter is a computer hacker!"As you can imagine, I was amazed. A computer hacker in my own house! I began to monitor my son's habits, to make certain that Cindy wasn't just telling stories, as she is prone to doing at times.After a few days of investigation, and some research into computer hacking, I confronted Peter with the evidence. I'm afraid to say, this was the only time I have ever been truly disappointed in one of my children. We raised them to be honest and to have integrity, and Peter betrayed the principles we tried to encourage in him, when he refused point blank to admit to his activities. His denials continued for hours, and in the end, I was left with no choice but to ban him from using the computer until he is old enough to be responsible for his actions.After going through this ordeal with my own family, I was left pondering how I could best help others in similar situations. I'd gained a lot of knowledge over those few days regarding hackers. It's only right that I provide that information to other parents, in the hope that they will be able to tell if their children are being drawn into the world of hacking. Perhaps other parents will be able to steer their sons back onto the straight and narrow before extreme measures need to be employed.To this end, I have decided to publish the top ten signs that your son is a hacker. I advise any parents to read this list carefully and if their son matches the profile, they should take action. A smart parent will first try to reason with their son, before resorting to groundings, or even spanking. I pride myself that I have never had to spank a child, and I hope this guide will help other parents to put a halt to their son's misbehaviour before a spanking becomes necessary.1: Has your son asked you to change ISPs?Most American families use trusted and responsible Internet Service Providers, such as AOL. These providers have a strict "No Hacking" policy, and take careful measures to ensure that your internet experience is enjoyable, educational and above all legal. If your child is becoming a hacker, one of his first steps will be to request a change to a more hacker friendly provider.I would advise all parents to refuse this request. One of the reasons your son is interested in switching providers is to get away from AOL's child safety filter. This filter is vital to any parent who wants his son to enjoy the internet without the endangering him through exposure to "adult" content. It is best to stick with the protection AOL provides, rather than using a home-based solution. If your son is becoming a hacker, he will be able to circumvent any home-based measures with surprising ease, using information gleaned from various hacker sites.2: Are you finding programs on your computer that you don't remember installing?Your son will probably try to install some hacker software. He may attempt to conceal the presence of the software in some way, but you can usually find any new programs by reading through the programs listed under "Install/Remove Programs" in your control panel. Popular hacker software includes "Comet Cursor", "Bonzi Buddy" and "Flash".The best option is to confront your son with the evidence, and force him to remove the offending programs. He will probably try to install the software again, but you will be able to tell that this is happening, if your machine offers to "download" one of the hacker applications. If this happens, it is time to give your son a stern talking to, and possibly consider punishing him with a grounding.3: Has your child asked for new hardware?Computer hackers are often limited by conventional computer hardware. They may request "faster" video cards, and larger hard drives, or even more memory. If your son starts requesting these devices, it is possible that he has a legitimate need. You can best ensure that you are buying legal, trustworthy hardware by only buying replacement parts from your computer's manufacturer.If your son has requested a new "processor" from a company called "AMD", this is genuine cause for alarm. AMD is a third-world based company who make inferior, "knock-off" copies of American processor chips. They use child labor extensively in their third world sweatshops, and they deliberately disable the security features that American processor makers, such as Intel, use to prevent hacking. AMD chips are never sold in stores, and you will most likely be told that you have to order them from internet sites. Do not buy this chip! This is one request that you must refuse your son, if you are to have any hope of raising him well.4: Does your child read hacking manuals?If you pay close attention to your son's reading habits, as I do, you will be able to determine a great deal about his opinions and hobbies. Children are at their most impressionable in the teenage years. Any father who has had a seventeen year old daughter attempt to sneak out on a date wearing make up and perfume is well aware of the effect that improper influences can have on inexperienced minds.There are, unfortunately, many hacking manuals available in bookshops today. A few titles to be on the lookout for are: "Snow Crash" and "Cryptonomicon" by Neal Stephenson; "Neuromancer" by William Gibson; "Programming with Perl" by Timothy O'Reilly; "Geeks" by Jon Katz; "The Hacker Crackdown" by Bruce Sterling; "Microserfs" by Douglas Coupland; "Hackers" by Steven Levy; and "The Cathedral and the Bazaar" by Eric S. Raymond.If you find any of these hacking manuals in your child's possession, confiscate them immediately. You should also petition local booksellers to remove these titles from their shelves. You may meet with some resistance at first, but even booksellers have to bow to community pressure.5: How much time does your child spend using the computer each day?If your son spends more than thirty minutes each day on the computer, he may be using it to DOS other peoples sites. DOSing involves gaining access to the "command prompt" on other people's machines, and using it to tie up vital internet services. This can take up to eight hours. If your son is doing this, he is breaking the law, and you should stop him immediately. The safest policy is to limit your children's access to the computer to a maximum of forty-five minutes each day.6: Does your son use Quake?Quake is an online virtual reality used by hackers. It is a popular meeting place and training ground, where they discuss hacking and train in the use of various firearms. Many hackers develop anti-social tendencies due to the use of this virtual world, and it may cause erratic behaviour at home and at school.If your son is u

												I'm really not sure why this is on Steam when the Nine Inch Nails Soundtrack has been removed. It's understandable that the developers can't completely get the rights to the tracks, but if the music is going to be absent it may as well not be in the library at all. I've heard some people like it without it anyway as it adds to the atmosphere, but taking a feature out of a game just ruins the experience for me. Unfortunately the same fate happened with Quake II on here.

												Most of the games today, have good graphics and a sh.it or don't even have something you can call a gameplay..well, back in the day of 1996 where Quake was firstly released, games had in the monocle of today a "not so good" graphical engine, but they had a gameplay where you needed "skill"..I mean..              look at the timeline of the DOOM games:Take the first doom and compare it to the 4th from today..DOOM (1993):A very tricky to hardcored gameplay with a lack of ammunition and strategic well made maps with very good kept secret rooms and a frantic atmosphere.and of course:     YOU NEEDED A HELL LOT OF SKILLDOOM (2016):A game with a bit of the frantic atmosphere from of the original game, but with less lack of ammunition..    I mean..WTF ID-Soft?!    Back in the day, you had to kill as much demons with as less shots you could, to save ammunition because ammo packages were excitingly rare, compared to todays DOOM where you just have to chainsaw one lil' less demon to get a full ammo supply laying all over the place to keep on tearing yourself thru this game with the non-skill this game actually uses..WHAT THE ACTUAL &%!?#/I could have been sitting a five year old re.tar.ded kid with a parkinson syndrom in front of that screen to complete that game in less than 5 seconds..      ARE YOU SERIOUS?!Anyway..    this was just an example of how games changed over the years..BACK TO QUAKE!Well it was, it is and it will be still one of my favourite games of all time, whether somebody complains about the graphics or not!Thumbs up, nice game!

number of helpful: 3 of 10 people (30%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2012
												Quake is like Doom except the physics feel much nicer and you can jump, aim up and down and there's an increased emphasis on movement in general. The trade off is that there's smaller groups of enemies (rarely more than two at a time) and they're all a bit more bullet-spongey. The weapons can also be a tad unimaginative (no BFG here, just a gun that shoots lightning and chews through it's max amount of ammo in seconds).A lot of people dislike this game's visuals for relying a lot on the color brown. Personally, I don't mind this, as I feel that the more complex lighting and architecture of the maps (compared to Doom) compensates for this. That and the crappy low-poly monster models (that are still surprisingly well animated) combine with the rusted look of the game to create a wonderful aesthetic of low-tech creepiness. (I'd compare it to Silent Hill, but no part of Quake is ever set in a foggy town in the countryside - though there is at least one user-made map set in Innsmouth.)This game also has excellent sound design by NIN's Trent Reznor. Don't bother with that EpiQuake junk, the game's audio is perfect enough as it is ... and on that note, I have to explain exactly why I'm giving this a thumbs down, even though I've just been gushing about the game.It's because the Steam version doesn't include Trent Reznor's ambient soundtrack that Quake played off it's CD as in-game music. Unlike Hexen, there aren't any MIDI tracks or anything for the game to fall back on if the CD is missing - just nothing. The in-game sounds of wind and flickering torches are slightly more audible, and that's as good a compromise as you get.Now, I can understand the absence if it was a rights issue with Reznor, but that supposedly wasn't the case. Apparently, it was because when id put the Steam version of the game together (which runs in DOSBox) they couldn't figure out how to simply rip the tracks off the CD in OGG format and configure DOSBox to load those files in lieu of redbook audio. Maybe John Carmack was too busy working on his new engine for whatever that game no one cared about was called.Regardless, get Quake if you can find the original CD release on the cheap - which you probably will, as it's not a particularly rare game, nor one as valued by collectors as Doom (though be careful not to buy a  shareware version by accident). Alternatively, wait and see if this ever shows up on GOG.com - as those guys will probably put more effort into a basic digital release of this game than it's own developers.------------------TL;DR, Quake is a very good game, but don't buy it here or you will get a version without music.

number of helpful: 3 of 20 people (15%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												Quake is a classic FPS that, alongside Doom, helped Id Software codify the genre. How, I don't know, because Quake is an unbelievably boring game.The game's plot is, ostensibly, about fighting the Lovecraftian Old God Shub-Niggurath as she does... things. Which are bad. Quasi-demonic invasion from beyond the veil of space. As a Lovecraft fan this would seem rather encouraging... if in practice the game had any real plot at all. In practice the game is almost gleefully self-aware in how much its plot is a thin excuse to commit mass murder.Quake's "story" is broken up into four Episodes, of which I have admittedly only played the first two. The difference between the two seems to mostly be the upgrade of a single enemy type, and a slightly different wall texture. Any actual plot developments are mostly limited to easily-missed text blurbs at the end of each Episode, which mostly just seem to foreshadow the final boss.Gameplay-wise, Quake is a tedious, linear run-and-gun set in an endless parade of largely identical brown hallways against the same five brown enemies (with a few exceptions, like the odd miniboss and the very rare "Base" levels featuring soldiers and dogs, all similarly brown), in levels that offer no trace of setting, motivation, or purpose besides a playground to kill things on. The entire game could be proceedurally generated and you'd never notice.The combat itself is rather annoying. You're equipped with three main ammo types throughout the game - shotgun shells, nails, and rockets - and have two weapons for each, the second being a straight upgrade of the first (except for the grenade launcher and rocket launcher, which have different firing methods with different situational uses). In theory this weapon selection is servicable, but in practice it's rather lacking. Shotguns are the mainstay weapons of the game, probably to minimize the need to actually aim. Nailguns are vastly more effective weapons, basically being automatic weapons that have a degree of aim-assist to them, however their ammo is considerably more sparse and is burnt through much more quickly.None of this is really a dealbreaker, the truly annoying part is that this game is old enough to have multiple floors overlapping one another, but functionally lack the ability to look up or down. Star Wars: Dark Forces had a similar conundrum mostly solved by the fact that most weapons would aim up or down for you in a limited cone, and your enemies had similar limitations. However, in Quake the most common enemy by far is the Ogre, a stocky brute with a middling level of health and equipped with a chainsaw and a grenade launcher. Bullets shoot straight, but grenades arc with gravity and bounce around corners. Cue every single level filled to the gills with Ogres on high ledges where as often as not you can't hit them, but they will gleefully pelt an endless stream of grenades down on your head.Don't make the mistake of me blaming my dislike of this game on it's difficulty. I died plenty, but I'm describing the game's combat as "annoying," not "difficult." Quake's uncomplicated setup makes it difficult for anything to become legitimately unbalanced, but managable does not mean fun. And when you take combat that isn't particularly fun, a plot that barely exists, and repetitive, bland aesthetics, you get a game that has essentially no merits to recommend.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 23, 2014
												The thing is, most big budget shooters like Call of Duty have set the example for shooters, but they have set a bad example that has lead to the downfall of the FPS genre. It is actually kind of sad, really, to see that games like this one just aren;t made anymore. Quake ism prime example of a game made in a time when gameplay was put over graphics and story, which is how it should be for most FPS. One of the very first FPS rendered in true 3D graphics unlike games before it like Doom, Quake is filled with run-and-gun action, a variety of weapons and enemies, and John Romero's amazing level design. Sure, the graphics are certainly arcadie, but that is what gives the game it's charm. Unfortunately, the graphics and animations are a bit grainy on the steam version when compared to, say, the Dark Places source port. Another problem is that the music is misiing from the steam version, which isn't neccesary to enjot the game, but it would have been an nice addon. Overall, this game will give you far more action than almost any other shooter out there, and for a low price of 10 dollars, Quake is a game everyone needs to play. You are not a true FPS gamer if you haven't played Quake.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 23, 2014
												The thing is, most big budget shooters like Call of Duty have set the example for shooters, but they have set a bad example that has lead to the downfall of the FPS genre. It is actually kind of sad, really, to see that games like this one just aren;t made anymore. Quake ism prime example of a game made in a time when gameplay was put over graphics and story, which is how it should be for most FPS. One of the very first FPS rendered in true 3D graphics unlike games before it like Doom, Quake is filled with run-and-gun action, a variety of weapons and enemies, and John Romero's amazing level design. Sure, the graphics are certainly arcadie, but that is what gives the game it's charm. Unfortunately, the graphics and animations are a bit grainy on the steam version when compared to, say, the Dark Places source port. Another problem is that the music is misiing from the steam version, which isn't neccesary to enjot the game, but it would have been an nice addon. Overall, this game will give you far more action than almost any other shooter out there, and for a low price of 10 dollars, Quake is a game everyone needs to play. You are not a true FPS gamer if you haven't played Quake.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												Quake is one of the first FPS games that is fully rendered in 3D.  Now it is more of an interactive museum piece than an entertaining game, but still has a little charm for those who really fell in love with the FPS genre when it grew big.  The guns are creative and semi-traditional, as well as the enemies.  This is also one of the first games to offer enemies that will fight each other when they get caught in crossfire.  This game also was one of the first games to be openly modded, but most mods have not been carried over from the past.  Multiplayer mods have to be downloaded separately from the base game.  I still enjoy this game once in awhile, but this is one of those gems that is simply more hard rock than actual diamond.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												This game is fast-paced, frantic, loud, nervewracking, and a ton of fun. All of the weapons are fun to use and inventive, ranging from a most manly shotgun to the Fickle Finger of God...I mean, the Lightning Gun. The levels are well-designed deathtraps forcing you to think quick on your feet and rewarding you for exploration and skill. Quake is tough, but never made me want to rage quit during my entire playthrough of the game. All in all, this a game I can recommend on a whim to anyone who likes fast-paced old school shooters, but I should add a note to this review: If you are going to play this game (and you should, it's fantastic), you would do well to get a source port to play it on (I play Quake on a source port, hence the 1.8 hours on record). The version on Steam has no music, which is an integral part of any game's atmosphere and feel, Quake in particular. In addition, if you like eye candy (and if you have a beefy enough rig, why wouldn't you?), source ports are the way to go in that regard. You can get the necessary files right here on Steam, and for $10 USD, I don't see how you can go wrong. Quake is more than just a relic of a past era, it's an enduring classic that still manages to compel a jaded modern gamer like me to play it for hours on end. Give it a spin, if you haven't already.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
												This game still stands as a unique, abstract shooter with a thickly-dark atmosphere.   No storyline; just a series of demonic mazes and fast action.  I lost much of my youth caught up in the multiplayer aspect of this game.  Gameplay-wise, it's a  basic but smooth formula.  It offers a challenge that is purely skill based; not just on your aim; but your timing, prediction and almost gymnastic movement around the levels.I still think it's a technical marvel.  This was one of the first full-3D games; and the levels are deliberately vertical and abstract in their design.  Everything has long since been open sourced; as a coder it's intriguing to inspect the design from a kind of archeological perspective.When starting, you're given the option to choose which executable to run;  QuakeWorld (which was its brilliant online version - though surely not noob friendly), didn't work for me.   Perhaps with some technical tinkering you can get this to work.  (It was never straightforward back in the day anyway)I've tested the GLQuake option, is the hardware rendering option, this works without any issues.  I'm sure there are mods out there that improve the experience, though.Gamers today will probably never feel the same sense of awe and wonder and compelling multiplayer gameplay as we did when it released.  I'm kinda glad that games have moved on though, this game has a slightly discomforting pull, like it's almost half-living, a demon demanding my return.   As a skeptical atheist, it's beyond disturbing.My time with this game is done;  it was a strange friend that was always present, but I hardly miss.  It still quietly haunts my subconscious to this day.   Damn.

												Well, QUAKE. There is probably nothing more to say. One of THE best games of the golden era of ego shooters. As a child I wasted so many hours, alongside with DOOM, DUKE NUKEM and TYRIAN, it's unbelievable. It has'nt lost any of its flair and charme. I even play it on a crappy sofware 640x480 solution, since I played it that way back than. Almost twenty years? Holy f! Didn't hurt this game in any way and it aged beautifully!This game is and always will be a 10 out of 10 for what it is: A masterpiece!Unfortunately, the soundtrack from NINE INCH NAILS is not included. Thanks,  Steam. As usual. And the mission packs are excluded and I needed to buy them seperately. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 24, 2016
												For this Steam edition, be aware that you don't get any music at all in Quake. Apparently there is a work around, but when one purchases a game they should get the full content.  Otherwise, all seems to be well in the delivery of the game.Quake itself wasn't quite all the gaming public had hoped for back in the mid 90s.   The music, visual design and action seemed quite dull compared to the hell-ride that was Doom, whilst the "full 3D levels" didn't seem to impress as much with competition from console games such as Super Mario 64 and Tomb Raider - which both offered smooth character animations where Quake's creatures-from-the-abyss were very jerky...That said, this game still manages to be a mile stone in gaming history.  Its multiplayer culture was massive back in the day and for years to come, and somehow, there is a gritty and creepy menace to the games characters - the jerky animation is actually a strength in this regard.  While Doom was Id's finest hour, Quake is still a highlight for the Texas-based developer.  Go grab a horror/action soundtrack CD from an old film and set it running before loading up Quake, and you'll be pleasantly surprised how delightfully nasty this classic game can be...Oh, for those wondering how to look around with the mouse; open the console and type "+mlook" and press enter.

Posted: June 23, 2015
												"Classic" is an overused term in gaming.  Because to be classic, a game must catalyse a revolution in style at it's time of release. To be classic, a game must transcend the simplistic outcome of entertainment and  become a canonical representation of both the gaming industry and the zeitgeist. It must raise the bar inalterably. Even by this dizzying standard, QUAKE stands aloft as perhaps the game most deserving the title of "classic game" in the history of the medium.Continuing id Software's epochal hewing of the FPS out of the shapeless mass of code in the 1990s, QUAKE springboarded off of it's cousin DOOM and formulated the rules of the Shooter that remain strictly enforced today. With being the first of it's kind, QUAKE is a game of absolute purity and speed. Slick as a razors edge and twice as sharp: you can almost feel it's surgical incision as you traverse it's beautifully functional level design, weild it's mathematical precise weaponry and do battle with it's unprecdented opponents.Reading this, QUAKE may come across as more of an algorithm than a game. But it's biggest feature, as well as it's best one, is it's heart. It is clear that the game is a labor of passion created by geniuses. QUAKE's aesthetic finds itself in the deepest recess of a Lovecraftian nightmare, playing host to ornate keeps haunted by demonic servants of a dark god. When pitted against overwhelming and brutal hordes of monsters clearly on their home turf, QUAKE is a game that will surely send a twang of fear up the spine and a shot of adrenaline into the heart of all gamers, regardless of their tenure.So, as a gamer, you owe it to yourself to experience this paradigm changing piece of art. If you fancy yourself a Warrior-God of Shooters who feels that you can best any challenge that the industry has thrown at you in the proceeding 20 years, play it on hard. If you're a maniac, play it on Nightmare. Or if you just want to know what all the fuss is about, simply play it. Live it. Let it absorb you like a dark, swirling apocalyptic sky.All hail the legend that is QUAKE.

content:
Posted: March 16
												Such an Iccon of its time and every bit as groundbreaking as Doom was. This is where MP deathmatch began with the likes of Doom and Quake. The Singleplayer level design is built in such a way that it is always fun to explore. The levels are riddled with secret passages, areas and even secret levels. Modern games could learn a lot from games such as these when it comes to level design. The sounds are just as creepy as I remember them. The success of Doom 2016 shows that these types of games are still very playable with modern graphics. I very much hope that a new singlepayer Quake campaign will happen in very much the same way as it did with Doom. For fast paced twitch shooting and fun levels... you cant get much better than this!

content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												The obvious stuff-A great FPS, I'll say. Better than most choices these days, but IMO it doesn't beat its sequel or Unreal. Why is that, for me anyway? Because its sequel was my first game ever, I learned to love the sci-fi look on it and get used to it rather than the Lovecraftian style that I came to experience some time after. Same goes for the music, a lot of people are going to hate me for this but I dislike most of the music for this game, with the exception of its main theme and the 'base' theme of every first level of each area. I really like those two, the theme's badass and the base music is relaxing, in a way. I really hate one of the tracks, the one with the piano and then you hear a voice that's like hearing someone dragging their finger nail down a chalkboard. Seriously, that's what I hear everytime I hear the song and its headache-giving, to me anyway, don't let that affect what you might experience. Sorry if I did. :/This game IS less repetitive than Doom, I'll give it that, its great for what it is, MUCH better than CoD, BF, and so on. I know I kinda already said that before but I really need to get that out there. This game's great, but only if you have bought and played others that might be better.The Stuff you'd probably need to know before you buy the darn game-You start out at a Hub that lets you select your difficulty, you proceed to such difficulty and you enter another hub that allows you to select the area of which will allow you to gain a rune. Such runes allow you to gain enough power to gain access to find the game's boss. You collect the runes by reaching the end of the area, that being the area's last level. The first area is the only one that has a scripted boss, the others are all walking enemies, though they can be considered bosses too, the game can get much harder depending on the area's number. You can finish the game pretty quickly, and its also easily speedrunnable if you know how to. Its overall very fun and as I said, only get it if you already played stuff that could be better. Get it on a sale if you want, I am known for being cheap like an old man so I dunno, I always tell people to buy stuff on a sale because its totally worth it. :p

												Well. If you dont know about Quake your either 3 years old or a complete gaming virgin. And even then i would be surprised. Quake is to 3d shooters what Black Sabbath is to Heavy Metal (which should be listened to loudly while playing). From ID after the iconnic Doom games Quake is the first shooter to go properly three dimensional and pioneered the keyboard and mouse style controls of basicly all shooters made to date.Incredibly emersive even to this day especially played in the graphics excellerated mode "GL". As well as fantasicly terrifying sound this game will get your heart rate pumpingIn my humble opinion Quake was home to some of THE most hardcore online gamers in history. If you are a fan of the modern day shooter and are young enough not to of played Quake, pay hommage to all that you enjoy by diving head first into the world of Quake.(Take your time to set up the controls properly, a small hint, open the console with ` and type +mlook to activate freelook)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Quake is undeniable. If you're on this store page, you shouldn't need me to tell you how great Quake is, but I am here to assure you that, with a few little patches, you can still play the Quake of your memories.The Steam version, like most digital copies, doesn't include the soundtrack, and GabeN obviously doesn't much care for physical media, so there's not much chance of him sending you a CD. Don't dismay, though. There are all kinds of guides to get the soundtrack up and running, and what a difference it makes! The memories of countless hours spent fragging came flooding back. A few graphical tweaks, and the game actually looks as good as I thought it did the first time I saw it played.If you ever enjoyed Quake, or if you're some kind of child or mutant who's never played before, you owe it to yourself to drop the paltry sum, and experience this masterpiece of foundational game design (foundational to its genre, at any rate) again, or for the first time.

												Ah... Nostalgia. Simply put.Great level design, despite being somewhat maze-like. Sufficient ammo per level, and an absolutely vicious Hard Mode (just beaten it again on this difficulty before review), backing up that ammo statement (needed every shell/nail/rocket/cell, especially at the end), and Nightmare Mode.Always a fun challenge: 1 on 1 a shambler or 3 fiends at once with an axe.Or start some fun infights, like this one:Ogre (grenade launcher and chainsaw)vsZombie (fights by throwing chunks of himself at you)Guess the winner in that infight I started.Answer: The Zombie, believe it or not. I am not making this up. Those skinny ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s are durable, right? And yes, it not only survived, but killed the ogre by throwing his own zombie chunks at him. It was oddly amusing. Lasted 5 minutes. I had to open a beer for this (which I did. Worth it.). I have strange ways to amuse myself.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 16, 2013
												Oh Quake, how I love thee.  Quake II was my introduction into First-Person Shooter, and after I had absorbed as much of it as I could I went to its predecessor and played that.  And boy are they different games.The funny thing about Quake is how different the games have been.  First there is Quake with a gothic feel that isn’t far from the Doom mold. Then you have Quake 2, which wasn’t intended on being a Quake game until they were unable to gain the rights they were looking for, and decided to just use the name Quake II.  It has a very technological theme with aliens.  After which there was Quake III Arena, which took all the great things created and learned from Quake and Quake II’s multiplayer, making almost a third setting/storyline, with characters from previous ID titles.  And finally there is Quake 4, which is a direct sequel to Quake II, back the the technological aliens.  And there is rumor of the next Quake game going back to the gothic style.While the story isn’t entirely there, Quake is ultimately an excellent game.  And maybe it’s simply because I just played all the great games in the right order.  Where each game fed into the next, and really displayed how they were truly remarkable.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 17, 2013
												Ah, the Classic Quake. The first true 3D FPS game. 13 years on, how well has it aged?Surprisingly well actually. I suppose the first thing to note is that the game played a lot like DooM, I personally like to consider it one of the 3 DooM 3's also consisting of DooM64 and the actual DooM 3. But I Digress.Quake, as the first FPS to use actual Ploygons manages to hold up quite well, you have the basic DooM style controls, using the arrow keys to turn, Ctrl to shoot and WASD to move (That is unless you're using the Ultimate Quake Patch, but I'll get to that later). and it does feel like a well-rounded experience that manages to hold up today. Of course it has graphically aged poorly with Jerky animation (this can be fixed with the UQP) but to fully enjoy the game you have to put your mindset back in 1996 where the best looking 3D was Virtua Fighter, This game puts you in a realisting looking (for the time) environments and gives frigtening enemies that have never been seen before.Story Wise the game doesn't offer much, but the game doesn't really need to, you're just a guy (Who I like to call Quakeguy) who must stop evil creatures from an Alternate Dimension. It is sweet and simple.All weapons handle well, from the Shotgun, Nailgun, Their 'Super' Counterparts, Rocket Launcher, Grenade Launcher, all are simplistic in their design and manage to hit their target with a bit of help from auto aim (Again, UQP). The game features a fun Fast paced game that is perfect for speedrunners and delivers on the retro feeling and boasts great level design.The Enemies themselves are actually made creepier with an effect that would not exist if the game had more polygons, The Gothic scenery makes the mood and feel of the game and gives the game It's own unique identity.Unfortunatly the game has some problems cause by some sort of steam optimisation. The Music is Non-Existant, even though there exists OST tracks on YouTube, none are featured in this game. This is Where the Ultimate Quake Patch comes into effect. The UQP fixes a lot of the Steam problems as well as some more of the poorly aged parts: Enemies have now got fluent animation, Mouse Control is Enabled, Improved Lighting and Particle effects as well as the OST added. Personally though I thought the 1996 graphics and improved lighting and effects were too distracting and I had no idea how to get the game to look like the Original game with just the Soundtrack so I removed it. The game still has a great Charm to it and is memorable for it's environments and enemies. The game is still fun without the UQP but may turn people off with the lack of soundtrack.I suppose the bottom line is that Quake is a Good, if not Great game the has fun retro gameplay but naturally has not aged well in many areas. This leads to 3 possiblities for interest in the consumers purchase:1) Buy the game on GOG where it (apparently) plays Just like the Steam release but with working OST2) Buy on Steam with UQP, if you aren't bothered by the clashing graphics and enjoy updated versions of old games then this should be fine for you3) Just buy the Steam release as it is and Play some 'Through the Fire and Flames' to the game and enjoy it for what it is.Quake is a Landmark in the FPS genre that doesn't hold up as well as it's older brothers DooM and Wolfenstein but leaves it's mark in it's creative level design and fun fast gameplay.FINAL VERDICT: RECCOMEND

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												That's the kind of game that I shall remember until the end of my life. It was the first 3D FPS that I've ever played and how amazed I was for being able to contemplate enemies that had depth instead of simply being made of some thin texture that would always stare at me (even when dead). The campaign mode is awesome, not only because of the gameplay, music, weapons etc, but also because you have the opportunity of playing it cooperatively with your friends. Talking of multiplayer, although Quake was so innovative back then, it also had to bear the weight of handling dial-up connections from most of the players (except in LANs), making the overall multiplayer conditions somewhat unfair. That's simply because some players had a better connection than others. I've played countless hours of CTF and later Team Fortress (how I miss those crafty grenades and maps). Besides that, I can't remember how many demo videos I've seen in-game, another wonderful resource that created a legacy. Oh well, if I may summarize this game in a single word, it can be only this: Epic.

												Ah... Nostalgia. Simply put.Great level design, despite being somewhat maze-like. Sufficient ammo per level, and an absolutely vicious Hard Mode (just beaten it again on this difficulty before review), backing up that ammo statement (needed every shell/nail/rocket/cell, especially at the end), and Nightmare Mode.Always a fun challenge: 1 on 1 a shambler or 3 fiends at once with an axe.Or start some fun infights, like this one:Ogre (grenade launcher and chainsaw)vsZombie (fights by throwing chunks of himself at you)Guess the winner in that infight I started.Answer: The Zombie, believe it or not. I am not making this up. Those skinny ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s are durable, right? And yes, it not only survived, but killed the ogre by throwing his own zombie chunks at him. It was oddly amusing. Lasted 5 minutes. I had to open a beer for this (which I did. Worth it.). I have strange ways to amuse myself.

												Such an Iccon of its time and every bit as groundbreaking as Doom was. This is where MP deathmatch began with the likes of Doom and Quake. Modern games could learn a lot from games such as these when it comes to level design. The sounds are just as creepy as I remember them. The success of Doom 2016 shows that these types of games are still very playable with modern graphics. I very much hope that a new singlepayer Quake campaign will happen in very much the same way as it did with Doom. For fast paced twitch shooting and fun levels... you cant get much better than this!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												Quake is one of the first FPS games that is fully rendered in 3D.  Now it is more of an interactive museum piece than an entertaining game, but still has a little charm for those who really fell in love with the FPS genre when it grew big.  The guns are creative and semi-traditional, as well as the enemies.  This is also one of the first games to offer enemies that will fight each other when they get caught in crossfire.  This game also was one of the first games to be openly modded, but most mods have not been carried over from the past.  Multiplayer mods have to be downloaded separately from the base game.  I still enjoy this game once in awhile, but this is one of those gems that is simply more hard rock than actual diamond.

												One of the best old school FPS games you can find out there.Fight against mind controlled grunts, evil hell knights and eldritch horrors as you fight to save Earth from being taken over by a supernatural force from beyond.You will be amassing a lethal arsenal of weapons including a double-barreled shotgun, nailgun, the classic rocket launcher and much more as you fight your way through slipgate facilities, old monestaries and castles as well as caves where your foes lie in wait to send you to an early death.Do you have the guts to descend into the dark depths and confront the source of the invading forces and put an end to this before it is too late?

content:
Posted: May 12, 2012
												Simply put, my favorite FPS of all time.  Impeccable level design, great enemies with really good AI for the time, and an environment and mob placement that actually lends itself to be legitimately scary.  It has surprises that you're usually ready for, but you're not the golden god you are in most FPS games where after the initial startle, you realize you can not be stopped and then wait until the next cheap shock.  Brilliant weapons, an awesome soundtrack and very cool odes to Lovecraftian lore make this a title that no gamer should ever have to claim they have not played.  If you love the Halos and Call of Duties now and have not taken a step back in time to play this gem, then make sure to put it on  your list.  You won't regret it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 22, 2013
												Truly one of my favorite video games of all time. For the time, the graphics were stunning and unfathomable. Even in an age of much better graphics, I still thoroughly enjoy looking about the levels and marveling at the superb design. The soundtrack is very fitting with the atmosphere that is placed around and creates a sense of immersion. The story is not clearly explained and is not emotional or anything but compelling enough to keep you blasting through enemies and exploring the environment. The gameplay is what to be expected, a fantasically crafted simple yet enjoyable first person shooter that screams everything is classic about this game. I would recommend this game to anyone in the world, even if they do not play video games often. This is a must play for anyone and everyone, this fine piece of gaming history should be known to all.  Quake is not just a game, but a whole culture that has culminated a certain part of video game history that still stands today in 2016. As one of my favorite games, even today, I can recommend this game to anyone. The graphics are not the absolute best, but were still revolutionary at the time. The sound is nostalgic to all of those that stayed up late nights playing with their friends blasting eachother with the crazy fun arsenal of weapnry. The environments took you to places that were quite unique for the time and somehow made sense to be designed the way that they were and not only that, but enjoyable to the average gamer. Furthermore, I think if the graphics get to you now, there are still modders that have improved on that to either get new players to experience it or bring some older players a new experience.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												An absolutely fantastic game with smooth gameplay despite it`s age. The overall design and atmosphere within the game is astounding and can be genuinely frightening if played on higher difficulty settings such as nightmare, not through arbitrary and scripted sequences, but through the enemy design and gameplay. HOWEVER, I must stress that despite this, a newer sourceport such as quakespasm or darkspaces is recommended due to the original engine not having aged too well.I personally recommend Darkplaces due to it`s compatibility and options such as FOV sliders and customisable lighting and effects, allowing you to give the game some visual upgrades.The weapons all serve great purpose and some damage enemies better than others, combined with the unique behaviour of each, the player is left with a game of great challenge and intrigue. The game features a well composed soundtrack by Nine inch nails and their logo can be seen on ammunition containers throughout.While the game is definitely not perfect, it is a game that any oldschooler would be incredibly comfortable with, however newschool players may find it less.Overall a solid gold piece of the past, not for everyone but for me, it was a good time.

												OK this time this one is for the STEAM AWARDS.I played Quake 1 in 2002 for the first time, and it's still a great first person shooter in all time.Quake is fast, wild, speedy, furious, goreness, bloody, dark, crazy, incrediblely fun. And Quake requires raw skills to beat. It's one of the kings of the thrones of the early 3D FPSes among with Unreal which make your dizzy, vomitting, adrenined. It makes the weak want to quit the PvP electronical sports until years later they can play Counter Strike or Call of Duty. It makes your little sister and brother admire you more. It makes your future son never dare to challenge your FPS domination. It makes your parents hate video games brainlessly. It makes your schoolmates stun and your old Pentium II 450MHz processor with Voodoo 2 graphics card burning besides the crying of your Microsoft mice. It makes you a special person who has the balls to tell the differences of different monitors which support 120Hz or 144Hz refresh rate between 60, 90, 120, 180 framerates. It make you seem like to be a insider of Ang Lee's Billy Lynn's Long Halftime Walk at its best of 4K resolution with 120fps. And after all, it makes you never be afraid of any 3D sickness and years later laughing and having fun in Virtual Reality while the others can only play just minutes.If human race will vanish, and there is only one FPS game can be saved. I will recommend Quake along with the sound tracks made by Trent Reznor and Nine Inch Nails.I don't play much Quake on Steam, mostly on an old copy I get from retail with GLQuake executables. New community mods make old Quake so fresh and shinny that almost a modern game with incredible lightening and shadow effects. Still a bad♥♥♥♥♥I would recommend Quake to anyone who's interested in first person shooter.

content:

												Ah... Nostalgia. Simply put.Great level design, despite being somewhat maze-like. Sufficient ammo per level, and an absolutely vicious Hard Mode (just beaten it again on this difficulty before review), backing up that ammo statement (needed every shell/nail/rocket/cell, especially at the end), and Nightmare Mode.Always a fun challenge: 1 on 1 a shambler or 3 fiends at once with an axe.Or start some fun infights, like this one:Ogre (grenade launcher and chainsaw)vsZombie (fights by throwing chunks of himself at you)Guess the winner in that infight I started.Answer: The Zombie, believe it or not. I am not making this up. Those skinny ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s are durable, right? And yes, it not only survived, but killed the ogre by throwing his own zombie chunks at him. It was oddly amusing. Lasted 5 minutes. I had to open a beer for this (which I did. Worth it.). I have strange ways to amuse myself.

content:
Posted: April 23, 2016
												The game itself stands the test of time, so a thorough review of the game on here would be redudant. For people new to Quake and would like to play it, you can try the shareware version online for free before you decide you want to buy it. If you decide to buy it, you can buy the game files from Steam, GOG.com, or even buy the retail copy from Amazon.com or Ebay.com if you want the CD-ROM, either way you'll be buying Quake. Please note that the Steam version does not include the music for the game and must be downloaded separately as long as you purchased a copy of the Quake game files. The GOG.com version includes the music files which may be added to the \id1\music directory in your QUAKE folder. To get Quake running on WinXP and up, download an updated version of the Quake engine (I recommend FitzQuake or Quakespasm for an authentic Quake experience) and follow the instructions listed on <https://www.quaddicted.com/quake/installation> (QUAKE may also be installed on Linux and Mac). You can also play custom maps from other Quake players on <www.quaddicted.com>. If you're interested in making custom maps yourself, check out <http://icculus.org/gtkradiant/> and download GtkRadiant. Happy playing!

content:
Posted: April 6, 2016
												This game looks rubbish. It should be rubbish?Oh no, oooo no kiddies of graphical fidelity and micro transactions. You may need a mod to play at 1920x1080 so whatever time I've spent won't be recorded. I've only played the first few levels and have already had fear, frustration and joy from this game. Joy being the primary feeling. It's simple, but the fundamentals of good level design and gameplay are there. Start playing for more than 10 minutes blasting bad guys and soon you're in another shooter. You still want them dead and your charecter alive. It doesn't matter that they're blocky and featureless. They're still evil mothers trying to stop you doing whatever the heck this game is trying to get you to do. I guess pest control from the looks of it and they're angy. But you've got low poly kick♥♥♥♥♥guns that sound... well they sound like a game from 97 with some being pretty decent.The enemies are actually interesting. Some can't be defeated by certain weapons and if you've only ever played quake 2 (like I had) then it's fun to see the recycled boxes and mechanics in different monsters and it's easy to see how the developers could see strogg in these weird mutants from hell beings. Some will launch, fire grenades and be hard to kill. Levels are interesting with limited puzzle elements and the completion time at the end of each level with the number of enemies reminds me of mario. Oh, did I mention you have an axe? I'm using the ezquake mod for quake 1 that cleans up the graphics a bit and allows you to run it in 1920x1080 although I found I had to use the load command from the console with the saved files name. It saves just fine, just won't load via the menu.Anyway. I'm actually impressed. I feel like I've had my own avgn episode, but instead of playing a rubbish game I've come out playing something awesome! Even as this game ages and looses it's looks it's kinda like your grandma. She's old and haggard on the outside, but when you engage you discover the fantastic person and the awesome things she did. She was sexy in 97.Quake will never be pretty again, but it will always be awesome and for that it's worth your time. Maybe it's time to go and play the original doom too before the newest one comes out. Oh right. And before you expect some fantastic single player quest and campaign. Forget it. There's no 10 minute man feeling scenes here, it's you, your gun and that monster your blasting into oblivion. Go nuts.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2016
												For this Steam edition, be aware that you don't get any music at all in Quake. Apparently there is a work around, but when one purchases a game they should get the full content.  Otherwise, all seems to be well in the delivery of the game.Quake itself wasn't quite all the gaming public had hoped for back in the mid 90s.   The music, visual design and action seemed quite dull compared to the hell-ride that was Doom, whilst the "full 3D levels" didn't seem to impress as much with competition from console games such as Super Mario 64 and Tomb Raider - which both offered smooth character animations where Quake's creatures-from-the-abyss were very jerky...That said, this game still manages to be a mile stone in gaming history.  Its multiplayer culture was massive back in the day and for years to come, and somehow, there is a gritty and creepy menace to the games characters - the jerky animation is actually a strength in this regard.  While Doom was Id's finest hour, Quake is still a highlight for the Texas-based developer.  Go grab a horror/action soundtrack CD from an old film and set it running before loading up Quake, and you'll be pleasantly surprised how delightfully nasty this classic game can be...Oh, for those wondering how to look around with the mouse; open the console and type "+mlook" and press enter.

Message me if you would like to modernize the game and are unsure what to do. Or just go here https://www.quaddicted.com/ and do it for yourself. I personally use the DarkPlaces engine with texture smoothing turned off. I do not use any high resolution texture packs or new models, as I prefer to play reminiscent of when I originally play, just with better lighting and high resolution. I keep this game installed on my PC as I'm always down for a game of Quake. The multiplayer community is still there. Quakeworld is fine, or go check out www.quakeone.com

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 26, 2016
												Quake is everything that the fans of the series claimed it would be. Quake follows the ranger (the protagonist) as he goes about collecting the 4 legendary runes in order to stop the Shub-Niggurath. The theme of interdimensional beings invading Earth seemed to be a popular theme among the time. The game is split into 4 episodes and the final boss fight. You can access any episode from the hub which has a great layout that I really enjoyed. Each episode is a decent length with around 7 or 8 levels, and the levels themselves usually have a few puzzles in order to keep you from just speed running it like in the DOOM franchise. The movement is fast paced allowing for you to easily out maneuver your opponent, while also keeping things from getting stale. The weapons in Quake are all unique in their own way some more useful than others. The enemies of Quake seem to share an eldritch horror style and are each unique with some requiring certain weapons to defeat them. The graphics in Quake invoke a nostalgic feel but are also heavily outdated. I did not play the multiplayer as I am sure that there are few servers if any at all still running. Quake does everything right that I wanted from a game like Doom and I had a fun time going through the story and playing through this gem of a game.

												recent playthrough left me in love with the game all over again, ive played this game countless times since my early childhood and nothing else compares in terms of single player FPSthe movement tech, allowing you to flow with style through maps as smoothly as a hot♥♥♥♥♥♥through vaseline... even games later in the series dont let you bhop and strafe jump as good as this classic. great for anyone who loves FPS with great movement and shooting mechanics. absolutely nothing else comes close to how tuned quake is for FUN fps gameplay.get it, play it, love itone consideration, the steam version comes with WinQuake, GLquake, and Quakeworld/GLquakeworld versions. none of these versions use music off the HDD, which means the default steam install does NOT include the amazing trent reznor soundtrack. it is a MUST to download the darkplaces sourceport and the missing music patch from the steam forums if you want the complete experience. darkplaces has some issues with multiplayer but you can easily swap to quakeworld/GLquakeworld if you want to play over over the internet.if you want to deathmatch it will probably be best to just go buy quake live though.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 6, 2016
												This game looks rubbish. It should be rubbish?Oh no, oooo no kiddies of graphical fidelity and micro transactions. You may need a mod to play at 1920x1080 so whatever time I've spent won't be recorded. I've only played the first few levels and have already had fear, frustration and joy from this game. Joy being the primary feeling. It's simple, but the fundamentals of good level design and gameplay are there. Start playing for more than 10 minutes blasting bad guys and soon you're in another shooter. You still want them dead and your charecter alive. It doesn't matter that they're blocky and featureless. They're still evil mothers trying to stop you doing whatever the heck this game is trying to get you to do. I guess pest control from the looks of it and they're angy. But you've got low poly kick♥♥♥♥♥guns that sound... well they sound like a game from 97 with some being pretty decent.The enemies are actually interesting. Some can't be defeated by certain weapons and if you've only ever played quake 2 (like I had) then it's fun to see the recycled boxes and mechanics in different monsters and it's easy to see how the developers could see strogg in these weird mutants from hell beings. Some will launch, fire grenades and be hard to kill. Levels are interesting with limited puzzle elements and the completion time at the end of each level with the number of enemies reminds me of mario. Oh, did I mention you have an axe? I'm using the ezquake mod for quake 1 that cleans up the graphics a bit and allows you to run it in 1920x1080 although I found I had to use the load command from the console with the saved files name. It saves just fine, just won't load via the menu.Anyway. I'm actually impressed. I feel like I've had my own avgn episode, but instead of playing a rubbish game I've come out playing something awesome! Even as this game ages and looses it's looks it's kinda like your grandma. She's old and haggard on the outside, but when you engage you discover the fantastic person and the awesome things she did. She was sexy in 97.Quake will never be pretty again, but it will always be awesome and for that it's worth your time. Maybe it's time to go and play the original doom too before the newest one comes out. Oh right. And before you expect some fantastic single player quest and campaign. Forget it. There's no 10 minute man feeling scenes here, it's you, your gun and that monster your blasting into oblivion. Go nuts.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2016
												Mannnnnnnn what do I even say? I was raised an id kid. I remember being in the single digits and sitting in a chair next to my Mom and Dad, watching them play Wolfenstein/Doom/Doom2. I was too scared to actually play it myself then, it took me awhile to work up the courage to try it myself, but when I finally did...the rest is history. We played and replayed those early id games for years, and then finally Quake came out. My parents weren't into the transition into 3d, but me, I saw the future in this game, it is responsible for so much.In my eyes, Quake 1 still remains the most excellent FPS you could ever hope to play. ESPECIALLY the multiplayer. I still think Quake 1 far outweighs even the might Quake 3 in simplicity and fun factor. It's just so damn fun and adrenaline-pumping to play, even now. I'm still addicted, even now, after all these years....So in modern reviewing format:Quake gets 420 no-scopes out of 10.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 3, 2011
												While modern iterations of the Quake franchise continue to attract new players, there has recently been a clear recognition of the true importance of the very first Quake in shaping the multiplayer FPS games we play today. Clients such as ezQuake, nQuake, and FuhQuake all continue to prolong the multiplayer life of this true classic as well as adding the various options, toolsets, and graphical improvements that most are familiar with today. From Dennis 'Thresh' Fong winning John Carmack's Ferrari 328 at the 1997 Red Annihilation Tournament to the current Quake Live MLG, CPL, Intel Masters, Tek9, and QuakeCon events (to mention just a few), there has rarely been a lapse in the competitive interest this game continues to generate.It is now 20 years since the game's release and there are simply too many happy memories to recount. Without a doubt one of the greatest games ever made and an essential title in any game collection.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 27, 2015
												Ah, the good old Quake. I remember back in 1996 how eagerly I awaited the CD-ROM with this gem. This was truly next-gen back in the day, and although still MS-DOS based at the time, it was a huge leap forward from the so common sprite based "2D/3D" shooters. This was true 3D, polygon monsters and a dark and foreboding atmosphere.I have largely absconded plain 3D shooters these days, because, frankly, I find them boring. Ten or fifteen years ago the FPS genre was at its prime, with a constant stream of new titles, MODs, re-releases of the same engines with a different graphic set and plot, and I can honestly say I probably played most of them. Nowadays a plain and simple FPS game just doesn't feel that entertaining anymore. It's all been seen and done before. So; what's a gamer to do? Easy. Go back into the past and relive the glory days with the good old quality FPS titles from that era.While it's true that the music is missing from this release, and while Nine-Inch-Nails are definitely a great choice, the game itself is still the fast-paced mayhem you remember (or not). I would strongly recommend to get "Quakespasm", since that allows you to play the game as close to the original as possible, but with Keyboard and Mouse and in HD resolutions. GLQuake doesn't work all that well. If you rename "quakespasm.exe" to "winquake.exe" in Steam's game folder (making copies of both files first of course), Steam will even count your play time.This is truly a classic. If you're looking for an 'old skool' FPS game that was pretty much paving the way for the new era of shooters, then look no further. If you like FPS games, there is no excuse for not having this in your library.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
												This game still stands as a unique, abstract shooter with a thickly-dark atmosphere.   No storyline; just a series of demonic mazes and fast action.  I lost much of my youth caught up in the multiplayer aspect of this game.  Gameplay-wise, it's a  basic but smooth formula.  It offers a challenge that is purely skill based; not just on your aim; but your timing, prediction and almost gymnastic movement around the levels.I still think it's a technical marvel.  This was one of the first full-3D games; and the levels are deliberately vertical and abstract in their design.  Everything has long since been open sourced; as a coder it's intriguing to inspect the design from a kind of archeological perspective.When starting, you're given the option to choose which executable to run;  QuakeWorld (which was its brilliant online version - though surely not noob friendly), didn't work for me.   Perhaps with some technical tinkering you can get this to work.  (It was never straightforward back in the day anyway)I've tested the GLQuake option, is the hardware rendering option, this works without any issues.  I'm sure there are mods out there that improve the experience, though.Gamers today will probably never feel the same sense of awe and wonder and compelling multiplayer gameplay as we did when it released.  I'm kinda glad that games have moved on though, this game has a slightly discomforting pull, like it's almost half-living, a demon demanding my return.   As a skeptical atheist, it's beyond disturbing.My time with this game is done;  it was a strange friend that was always present, but I hardly miss.  It still quietly haunts my subconscious to this day.   Damn.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
												A hardcore and excellent example of a simple concept perfected. I love the atmospere and over the top action. The only problem I had with the game is that opengl didn't work on my fancy desktop, yet it ran smooth as silk on my crappy laptop. Also no music or any ambient sounds at all, but there are work arounds for the audio. Overall a very competent package but the asking price is a little steep in my opinion, maybe 5-6.99.
